name: Bruno on the Pacific Crest Trail
summary: My journey hiking from Mexico to Canada!

all_steps.name: The Pacific Crest Trail
all_steps.description:
Hello everyone!
I'm gearing up for an epic journey: thru-hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, or PCT. Spanning over 4,200 kilometers, this trail stretches from the US/Mexican border in California to the US/Canadian border in Washington, traversing through three american states: California, Oregon, and Washington.
Thru-hiking the PCT is a massive undertaking that requires careful planning and preparation. It passes through a diverse range of landscapes, from desert valleys to snow-capped mountain peaks, and presents various challenges along the way, including steep ascents, unpredictable weather, and limited access to resources (like water and food 😅).
As I embark on this adventure, I'll be sharing updates and insights about my journey, from the breathtaking scenery to the practical aspects of life on the trail. Stay tuned for updates as I tackle this incredible adventure from south to north, one step at a time!
Until then,

Bruno 🗺️

all_steps.name: Serendipity
all_steps.description:
I remember the exact date, the exact moment that I heard about the PCT for the first time.

It was my second winter living in Amsterdam, morning of January 27th 2017. At that time I was already planning my first long hike ever (Camino de Santiago) that was set to start in exact three months, but I had no idea that hiking would become one of my biggest passions in life. 

Three years earlier (2014) when I still lived in Brazil, I met one of my best friends, Gabriela. During one of our first random conversations she asked me if I had heard about Creative Mornings. No, never, I said. She explained  to me what it was about and I decided to give it a try and went to a few events in São Paulo. Later, after moving to Amsterdam, I attended a few more (they organize events all around the world).

It was In one of these events (the fifth that I attended in Amsterdam) that Tim Voors, the speaker (that I had never heard about) of that event talked about the PCT (this crazy hike that I also had never heard about). I didn’t even know that this would be the subject of the talk when I subscribed to the event. As always, I wanted to attend because I enjoyed the vibe and the overall inspiration that the creative community brings together. At that time, I had no idea that all these things that I didn’t know combined were about to change my life forever.

I love these coincidences. I love these bits of inspiration that you can get because people decided to share their passions and their adventures with other — sometimes random — people. I love to find things that I didn’t know that I was looking for.

Thank you Gabriela for introducing me to Creative Mornings. Thank you Tim for sharing your story and inspiring random people like me (even though you don’t know me and you’re most likely not reading this 😅)

And thank you all for following this journey along with me. I hope I can also inspire some of you 💜

all_steps.name: Gratitude
all_steps.description:
“Journey North” was the first book that I read about the PCT, two years ago. The book, written by Barney “Scout” Mann, tells his story about thru hiking the PCT in 2007 together with his wife, Frodo. 

Since then, every spring they open their home in San Diego to host hikers from all over the world before they start their own PCT. I’m fortunate enough to be staying with them for the coming two nights.

After more than 12 hours flying (plus passport control, plus train, plus 40 minutes walking) I arrived at their house. As soon as I rang the bell, Rolling Thunder came to welcome me with the biggest smile. Right after him, I see Scout as he says “Welcome, Bruno. I’m glad to have you here”. A third person hands me a warm and fresh plate of food. I was completely (and positively) overwhelmed. 

Around 25 hikers stay here every night during the hiking season. Scout and Frodo (with the help from other fantastic volunteers) cook dinner and breakfast for us every single day. They also receive packages, organize trips to the sports store and supermarket and give us tips and motivation to the adventure that’s about to start. After dinner Scout told us beautiful (and sad) stories about the PCT and urge us to be kind along the way. Frodo gave us the best advice possible: make wise decisions.

They don’t accept any kind of gift or donation (other than words). They say they’re fortunate enough to be able to do that and, in exchange, they ask us to be nice to each other and with the trail. They ask us to help any other hiker in need. They also remember us not to be afraid to ask for help when we need. And they make it very clear that, at some point during the PCT, everyone will need help.

Right now, I feel like I’m the luckiest person in the world. And I can only think of one word: gratitude.

all_steps.name: Campo
all_steps.description:
After another delicious breakfast at Scout and Frodo it was time to say goodbye and take the shuttle to the Southern Terminus of the PCT where I would be camping and then start the hike tomorrow.

On the way, we stopped by at the local sports store to find the last-minute equipments and supplies. They had a nice Welcome section for PCTers.

At Cleef (the camping place where I’m spending the night today), I met Clara (Hi Clara!! 👋).

We set camp, had an awesome evening with burritos, beers and talks about the dangers of the PCT. Today I learned the rule number one of the PCT: don’t die. Noted ✅

I quickly went to grab my official PCT tag 🏷️ to attach to my backpack. 

Tomorrow I start hiking the PCT. 🤯

all_steps.name: So it begins
all_steps.description:
Day 1
PCT Southern Terminus to Lake Morena
PCT Miles: 20 (32km)
Total Miles: 20 (32km)

It’s happening!!

Today I went with Clara back to the Southern Terminus to take a proper PCT first day picture and to stick our arms to Mexico. We were blessed with a beautiful, beautiful sunrise!

After that we went back to Cleef to have breakfast. What a magical place! Some people cowboy camped (camping without a tent) and they were drying up their sleeping bags: because of the cold and condensation, their sleeping bags literally froze overnight 🥶. We had chocolate chips pancakes prepared by Papa Bear and headed out to our first PCT day!

Soon after we started, we were joined by a group of 4 people and the six of us hiked together for most of the day. If it’s not obvious, the desert is so hot and dry. The challenge for today was to constantly carry just the exact amount of water to reach the next water stream (and then, filter the necessary water to reach the next stream again). I drank around 6 liters of water during the hike (and drank 2 more now, arriving at camp).

Other than that, no major incidents. No rattlesnakes, no pooping in the wild yet. Just the last 5 miles were very exhausting because of the heat and the ascend to Lake Morena, where I’m staying tonight. We split the group and Clara stayed  a bit behind so I guess tomorrow I’ll be starting the day on my own 🐣.

I’m absolutely exhausted, but happy with the day. 2630 miles to go!

all_steps.name: Mount Laguna
all_steps.description:
Day 2
Lake Morena to Mount Laguna
PCT Miles: 21.5 (34.4km)
Total Miles: 41.5 (66.4km)

I woke up at 6 and I was starving. I spoiled myself with a 2-course breakfast. First I had a cup noodles. After that, I had fruit punch gatorade soaked granola, served on the unwashed noodles cup. I call it electronola! Delicious 😗👌!

At 8 I started walking and the day was much cooler than yesterday. By 12 I had walked 10 miles already.  The path was fun with some “river” crossings. And then, the heat showed up.

The afternoon was much tougher, not only because of the heat but also the ascend (it turns out that *Mount* Laguna is a mountain, who would have know?). I arrived at the recreational campground in Mount Laguna at 18:30 only to find out that it’s opening only next week. Since it was getting dark and cold, I was a little bit desperate. I asked some people around and they gave me a number of someone who could help me. I called and the lady told me she had a tiny house with no services (electricity, water) but I could have it for the night for $20. Tonight I’m sleeping like a king!

There’s also a restaurant nearby. After checking in at my beautiful tiny house, I had a salad (cheese salad apparently) and pizza! 

I just realized that even though I met quite a few people (including a big group that I met at Scout and Frodo’s), I hiked most of the day alone. I must say that I really enjoyed my company.

Tomorrow I’m leaving with food for three days and the next resupply is 60 miles away, so I have to keep the same rhythm for these last two days — not an easy task.

all_steps.name: 10 before 10
all_steps.description:
Day 3
Mount Laguna to mile 63.7
PCT Miles: 22.2 (35.5km)
Total Miles: 63.7 (101.9km)

I don’t remember the last time I slept so well! 8.5h of continuous sleep! On top of that, I had pizza for breakfast 🍕🤤! Perfect start of the day!

I started hiking at 6:30 and a few minutes later, I heard someone behind me calling my name. It was Max, the french dude that I hiked with on the first day.

We hiked together for the whole morning. By 10am we had hiked already 10 miles. 10 before 10! We kept this pace until 12:30 when we stopped to eat. After one hour or so I left Max behind and kept hiking for 3 more hours until I found a quite crowded campsite. It’s going to be my first night wild camping on the PCT! It’s crazy windy over here up the mountains 🌬️⛰️ !

Tomorrow it’s going to be a challenging day. I want to hike 21.6 miles to get a better campsite. The problem is that there’s only one water source. But they say sometimes magic happen on that stretch to provide water. We’ll see! 🪄💧

Because I finished the day early (and I don’t have internet!) I’m listening to music for the first time since I arrived in San Diego! 

Oh, also, I found out today that I have a blister. I’m calling her Bloopu. Short for Blood Pudding.

all_steps.name: Trail Magic
all_steps.description:
Day 4
Mile 63.7 to mile 86.6
PCT Miles: 22.9 (36.6km)
Total Miles: 86.6 (138.6km)

After sleeping for 11 hours (!!!) I woke up around 5 and right before 6 I was already hiking. Not much because I wanted to, but because I needed to beat the heat. Besides the forecast of 30 degrees and almost no shade, this section doesn’t have many water sources.

I hiked mostly alone (yay!) and did another 10 before 10, properly celebrated with my first snake sighting! It was not a rattle snake though, just a normal scary terrifying long random snake 🐍.

I kept pushing until Scissors Crossing, where most hikers hitch to Julian, a hiker’s town. I didn’t want to go to Julian, but I was out of water. Then, I experienced my first trail magic: right under a bridge (one of the few places with a shade today) there was a water cache! It’s a known cache, replenished every day (multiple times a day) by trail angels. While I was there having my lunch and resting (it was a pretty tough and warm morning), I saw someone coming with more water, tangerines, bananas and cold gatorades and leaving everything there for the hikers. I find it truly amazing and inspiring that people do that!

After a good two hours break it was time for the toughest part for me so far: the next water cache should be 14 miles ahead, which basically meant that I had to dry camp tonight: camping without a water source nearby. I started my afternoon carrying 5 liters of water, which almost doubles the weight of my backpack. For the next 10 miles I had absolutely no shade and I sweated like a madman. I can see stains of salt everywhere on my clothes. My face literally has a white layer on top 🧂!

I’m eating my dinner as I write this and now there’s only one meal left on my backpack! My plan is tomorrow to first not die and second hitch to store and resupply for the coming 4 days!

And yes, Marlos. Today I used my little shovel 😌

the heat hits hard
hard hits the heat
was that another snake
or just my heartbeat?

the scorching desert burns
my strength seems to fail
while the dry wind 
sucks all the moisture away

but then there are angels,
who bring magic to the trail
my hope is restored
my spirits are up again

i quench my thirst and once more
my body feels strong
and believe me, in return
i’ll pass the kindness along

all_steps.name: Ranchita Bodega
all_steps.description:
Day 5
Mile 86.6 to mile 101.2
PCT Miles: 14.6 (23.4km)
Total Miles: 101.2 (161.9km)

It was my warmest night in the PCT so far. I tried to use my sleeping bag only as a blanket, but it was still too warm. I could feel the old salt in my body mixing with new sweat. Not the best night of sleep, but that ended up being good: I enjoyed the night sky in the desert, with almost full moon. The moon so bright, no clouds and a sky full of stars ✨! 

After I woke up I had to make a decision: I only had one last meal and 15 miles ahead of me. I could eat now or save it for later. I decided to eat it before hiking, so at 5:30 I was eating pasta with chili for breakfast 😋!

The sunrise in the desert is absolutely beautiful 🌄!

Soon after I started hiking, Bloopu started to complain and I noticed that I was limping. Not a very good sign. After 6 miles, a very welcomed trail magic: water cache. I gulped down 1 liter and stocked up 2 more. I had now 2.5 liter for the remaining stretch of 10 miles. 28 degrees and no shade. No food. Limping.

Maybe the water was miraculous, because as soon as I left the water cache Bloopu got better. I could hike on a good pace and the more I hiked the more I drank, the lighter my backpack became. For the last 2 miles, I was carrying no water and no food. I felt like I was flying.

I crossed the 100 mile mark (4% of the PCT 🥲) and soon after I found myself in a parking lot. I knew that there’s a mini market 4 miles off trail, but you can call for a ride. I did and 10 minutes later Mike came to pick me and another hiker up. Brought us to the Ranchita Bodega!

I will resupply here for the coming 4-5 days. It’s going to be a challenge: hike with so much added weight.

I decided to stay in a room here for tonight. That means that I had my first shower! It’s amazing how many layers of dirt your body can accumulate.

I’ve just done groceries and washed my clothes (that’s why i’m wearing my rain pants) and I’m chilling on a hammock listening to Red Hot Chili Peppers playing at the shop. Life could be worse ✌️!

all_steps.name: First Resupply
all_steps.description:
I had the whole afternoon free yesterday, so I could do laundry, shower, rest, plan and resupply. I want to leave Ranchita with enough food until Idyllwild, 77 miles ahead. That’s about 4 to 5 days. Besides food, I also bought more fuel ⛽️ for my stove, sunscreen (my calves and lips are a bit sunburnt). The highlight is the dehydrated peanut butter 🤤🤤!

It was time for me and Bloopu to part ways. I had a needle and thread 🪡 that I got from Scout and Frodo and I knew the theory behind popping a blister and draining it out so you can keep hiking without it bursting into your dirty socks. I learned this before going to my first Camino de Santiago in 2017 but I very rarely have blisters (knock on wood 🤜💥🪵 ) and never needed to do it. 

After sterilizing the needle with fire and alcohol, I popped Bloopu and the blood started to leak through the thread. I left it for a few minutes and it was mostly dry! As I ran the remaining thread through the blister it sucked all the blood away! Perfect! I patched everything with plasters and so long, Bloopu 👋!

I also fully charged my devices, since I’ll be with little to no electricity and internet during the coming 4-5 days!

Time for a good night of sleep with sheets, pillow and unlimited filtered water. What a life!

all_steps.name: Ups and downs
all_steps.description:
Day 6
Ranchita Bodega (mile 101.2) to mile 119.6
PCT Miles: 18.4 (29.4km)
Total Miles: 119.6 (191.4km)

I had my first slow morning today. Mike would drive me back to the trailhead at 9, so I could chill until then. I called Maike 💜 and used the last chance to top up the batteries of all the electronic stuff. I decided to bring just enough water until the next water source (my backpack is super heavy with the food).

A bit before 9 Mike showed up and brought me and two more hikers to the trailhead. Selfie time!

My little toe was feeling great and I walked on quite a good pace for about 4 hours. At some point, there were some very curious cows on a mud path. It was all a bit wet with some puddles here and there. I tried to jump over one of the puddles... I slipped and ended up falling on my back on the ground. Everything’s fine, nobody’s hurt but my whole back and my backpack were now covered by a mix of mud and cow’s juice. I hiked 3 miles smelling like cow and completely dirty.

After one and a half hour having to deal with
myself covered in that dark brown blerbh, there was a creek and I could wash everything. I wore everything back wet, which was actually quite refreshing. In less than an hour everything was dry again 🥵.

The path today was much more beautiful and less exposed than the previous days. There was a lot of oak trees providing shade and the ground was much softer. There were also some parts of desert 🌵 of course. 

Even though I was pretty pissed with the cow’s juice situation, my overall mood was very good today. There will be a stretch of 12 miles without water and I’ll have to dry camp tonight. That means that at some point I was carrying my full capacity of water: 5.5 liters. This is the heaviest my backpack has ever been! 

Even though the last miles of the day were uphill, everything was fine. I found a nice camp spot up in the mountain and I have just watched perhaps the most beautiful sunset of my life. Look at this sky!

all_steps.name: One week!
all_steps.description:
Day 7
Mile 119.6 to mile 140.6
PCT Miles: 21.0 (33.6km)
Total Miles: 140.6 (224.9km)

One week on the PCT! And still alive!! 🥳

Even though the night had been quite warm, I woke up a bit cold. As soon as I opened my tent, I realized why! Everything was very humid as I was in the middle of a dense mist. I tried to pack as soon as I could but the beauty of my surroundings made me a bit catatonic. I left camp at 6:40.

The morning was gorgeous! That was the most beautiful day I had in the PCT so far. For hours I could see from above the fog trapped in the valley. As the sun slowly showed up, the views of the top of the mountains over the fog were unbelievably beautiful. 

Not only the most beautiful day, but today was also the day where I had to carry 7.5 liters of water! I didn’t want to trust one of the water sources (a cistern that was rated as “dry and full of dead animals”), so my alternative was to hike 24 miles plus dry camping in one go. But for that, one of the other water sources, called Mike’s Place and maintained upon donations, had to be working. My morning was divided between hiking, admiring the surroundings and praying for water.

At mile 127, I saw a sign that I was hoping for: the directions to Mike’s Place. A few more minutes walking off trail and I could see the big water tank. And it had water. Maravilha!

Time to camel up (drink water at a source until you can’t anymore) and fill every single bottle I had. Total 7.5 liters and a backpack that I almost couldn’t lift. I think it weighted something around 17-18 kilos… 🥵

Slowly but steadily I kept hiking and very consciously drinking water. In a way I had to save water to be sure I’d  have water for 24 miles plus dry camping, but I also wanted to get rid of the weight as soon as I could.

I’m so happy that Bloopu is gone. My left foot is much much better. I’m not sure I could have carried so much weight if Bloopu was there. Unfortunately it seems that some relative of Bloopu is starting to show up on my right little toe. I’m sure you all are very interested in this topic so I will keep you posted!

Around 5pm and after 21 miles I decided to make camp. Maybe I didn’t choose the best place because it’s super windy, but there’s absolutely no chance that I walk another single mile today. I’m glad that I have a proper tent and not only a tarp like some people hiking the PCT.

Tomorrow there’s a famous Café that’s accessible hiking a bit off trail and I’m hoping to eat real food. Or as close as real food as you can get at an American Café 😅!

all_steps.name: A storm is coming
all_steps.description:
Day 8
Mile 140.6 to mile 162.7 (Cedar Spring)
PCT Miles: 22.1 (35.4km)
Total Miles: 162.7 (260.3km)

The day ended yesterday and started today with wind, a lot of wind. And it was windy for the whole day.

There are very few water sources in this part of the trail. I was excited to go to Paradise Valley Café, 1 mile off trail, so I could refill my water (and eat a vegetarian burger just in case). Also, I needed to go to get my micro spikes that I ordered last Sunday. Depending on a lot of factors, sometimes you need micro spikes (and an ice axe 🪓) for this part of the trail and sometimes not. Because I’m still trying my best not to die, I decided to carry micro spikes from today on.

It was a very efficient morning (10 before 10!) and Paradise Valley Café (PVC) didn’t disappoint: I had a nice beer, at least four cups of ice cold water, burger and fries. I also found my package 📦 amongst hundreds of others and refilled my water until the next water source.

I had to quickly go back to trail because I still had more than 12 miles ahead of me and today I was not carrying enough water to dry camp, so I had to make it to my next water source: a spring (Cedar Sprint) 1 mile off trail. Everything seemed fine.

Until the storm started to approach.

After leaving PVC I was hiking slow because I was heavy with all the water and the elevation went from 4 to 7 thousand feet 🦶 (whatever that is in meters). But the more I hiked the more I felt that I was hiking straight into the stormy clouds that were gathering. At some point the sun was hidden and the wind was blowing violently and it started to become chilly. I still had at least 3 hours to hike. I was so concerned about the storm that my first sight of a rattlesnake didn’t bother me much (and it was very close). I had only one goal: arrive at the spring before it started raining or getting too dark.

After rushing a bit and feeling the wind pushing me to the side for the last hour or so, I arrived around 18 and gladly there was enough space close to the spring for my tent. I’m happy that I could camp here, it seems more protected from the wind. The wind is so strong that it sounds like ocean waves crashing into rocks. 

Hopefully tomorrow the wind won’t be as strong, specially during the day. I still need to ascend 2000 feet and hike 16 miles with all the water for the day. My plan is to finish the day hiking off trail (through another trail called Devil’s Slide 👿🛝) into Idyllwild, my next resupply stop!

(today I hiked 3 miles off trail: 2 miles to and from
PVC plus 1 mile to Cedar Spring. For a PCT thru hiker there are only a few things worse than hiking non-PCT miles…)

all_steps.name: Into the storm
all_steps.description:
Day 9
Mile 162.7 (Cedar Spring) to Idyllwild
PCT Miles: 16.7 (26.7km)
Total Miles: 179.4 (287km)

I didn’t sleep very well with all the wind and the anticipation that today I would have the most challenging day on the PCT so far. Oh boy if only I knew…

I decided to have a coffee and a tea to warm me up before I left camp. One of the obvious advantages of camping close to a spring is that you have unlimited water. I wanted to wait for the wind to become less intense and for the cold and condensation on my tent to dissipate a bit.

Wearing for the first time my fleece and my gloves 🧤 I left camp at 8. 1 mile hiking up back to trail 🤬 and then off I went to… the middle of the storm.

To be fair, it didn’t rain (or snow or hail) but the wind was so strong and so cold that at some times I had to stop hiking just to keep my balance. Today I was not hiding under the trees for shade. I was hiding behind rocks or bushes for wind protection.

Not only it was a steep climb of more than 2000 feet to a maximum elevation on 8800 feet in was also not carrying so much water. I was hoping not to drink too much since it was not so warm. The problem is that the ascent took much more than I thought. It was super steep (and windy!!). Not only the physical effort was huge, I tried my best to keep it slow to prevent altitude sickness.

There were trees and branches and rocks spread all over the path. To be honest it really made the hike more fun (jump over or crawl under a tree, finding ways of going around impenetrable blobs of branches, etc) but it also made it so much slow. I was hiking under 1.5 mile an hour and that was simply not going to work.

Around lunchtime I passed this group of 4 people. As I usually do, I quickly stop to introduce myself, wish them a good day and carry on with my bike. Hi, I’m Bruno, I said. Toni, Noelle, Tenor and Virginia they replied! Have I nice day, I wished to them. You too, they replied. Oh by the way there’s something on in your fanny pack, Toni yelled. I noticed that
my headlamp was on for some reason. The light was very faint, so it probably was on for the whole
morning (and past evening?). I turned it off and yelled back: thank you!

At mile 169, I saw what I was absolutely not looking forward: snow and ice on the path. The first test was actually a steep cliff edge. Remembering the first rule (don’t die!) I decided to put my micro spikes on. But before, time to read the manual as I had no idea what I was doing… It turned out to be pretty straightforward and there I was, all micro spiked and ready for some ice and snow action!

Everything went fine. There was not thaaat amount
of snow and I felt safe all the time. It was just impossible to look down at the cliffs. Every step in inclined snow took me forever, which I don’t regret.

Even the sun decided to show up (after I was above the clouds). It was still very cold and windy but sunny. Maybe too sunny. I started drinking much more water and I was so relieved when I found a spring from melted snow running alongside a rock wall. Time to refill!

Because it took me so long to hike today, I decided not to go to Idylllwild and instead camp on top of the mountain. I heard that the descend to Idyllwild was a bit steep and there was a considerable amount of ice and snow. Better to do it tomorrow morning when my body is rested.

I couldn’t wait to make camp. I didn’t have more lunch food and I ate all my snacks during the day. The only thing left was a knorr spaghetti and a couscous, both I had to cook. I was really looking forward to a warm meal!

At 5 I finally found the last place to camp before the descend to Idyllwild. It was a beautiful place with a beautiful view to both sides of the mountain. I was alone and there was not much protection from the wind though, so I pitched my tent with some struggle. I used big rocks to secure my tent stakes in place. Everything good, time for some well deserved rest and warm food!

What a crazy day! While I was pitching my tent I thought that this was probably the most adventurous and challenging hike day I’ve ever had. So exhausting but so rewarding!

It indeed ended up being the most adventurous day of my life. But not for what had happened already, but for what was still to happen…

to be continued…

all_steps.name: Into the darkness
all_steps.description:
Day 9, part 2

I had just finished to pitch my tent and was admiring the beautiful view of the sun, clouds and mountains when…

SNAP! I hear something break and the metallic sound makes me sure it’s not just another branch.

I look back and my tent pole is broken, my tent flapping and swinging with the wind as if it was a weird flag attached to the ground. It took me a few seconds (or minutes) to assess the situation. The forecast is 4 degrees (surely colder here on top of the mountain), sustained winds of 40 mph (64km/h), cold and wet feet and no tent. It seemed difficult not to break the only rule I’m trying to follow here. What could I possibly do?

“Hiiii Bruuuunoooo” I hear. Holy shit, I’m delirious I think. I’m so exhausted that I’m hearing the wind saying my name.

“Bruno!!!” I hear, but now it’s a different voice. I can’t believe what I’m seeing.

Toni, Noelle, Tenor and Virginia were crossing the last patch of snow before where I am. When I met them earlier today we brielfly exchanged our plans: I was going to Idyllwild via the Devil’s Slide trail and they would be camping in the last camp spot, which is where we are now. My plan obviously changed and I’m so happy to see them!

Dude you’re crazy to camp here with this storm, Tenor said. We’ll push to Idyllwild, he continued.

Once more I couldn’t believe what I was listening.

I looked at each one of them. They also looked exhausted. How are you guys possibly going to Idyllwild still? It’s going to take at least two hours and the path ahead is really full of snow, I asked. We know, but we won’t be here in this storm tonight. We’ll push it though, one of them said.

Can I please join you guys? I need five minutes to disassemble this… tent?

Of course! The four of them replied in unison.

There I was. 5:30 in the evening, exhausted and still a good 2-3 hours of hike ahead of me. Let’s do this!

The evening was stunning. The sky was clear and even the wind was milder. And even though we had to hike mainly on ice and snow, it was not sketchy or dangerous at all (I guess).

I was happy to be with other people that had more experience than me in these conditions. Also, whenever something would happen, like somebody sinking knee deep jnto the snow, sliding or even falling, instead of thinking “oh shit I’m going to die” there was always a “are you ok?” checkup followed by some laughs. I didn’t realize that, but I missed laughing.

The problems was that we were slow. Besides the terrain not being the friendliest and us being super tired, we were stopping more than normal to take pictures. There was a beautiful sunset and nobody wanted to miss it. Until someone realizes that at the sunset, the sun… sets! We’re going to be in the darkness!

We started rushing a bit, but there was no way to espace our destiny. At some point some commanded: everybody: head lamps on! Yes, sir 🫡! I put my head lamp on and… yeah, I remembered that it had been on probably for the whole day and past night by accident, so I have no light. I stayed in the middle of the pack and thankfully their lights were enough to show me the way.

Then it was 7, 7:30, 8… and we were still in the mountain. At 8 we started our decent and at 8:30 there was — finally! — no more snow. We took off our micro spikes and started almost to run downhill. At 9:30 in the evening, after hiking in the complete darkness for more than one and a half hour, we arrived at the trailhead parking lot where a trail angel was waiting to pick us up. We couldn’t believe it (at least I couldn’t!). We all high fived and prepared to go to town!

Except…

We were five people. The trail angel rightfully only wanted to bring 4 at a time. Because I was new
in the group (and I was so thankful that they “rescued” me) I decided to stay. The trail
angel said she would be back in 20-30 minutes to pick me up. Before leaving, the trail angel said: please be safe, I’ll be back for you. And be careful with mountain lions, we do have some in this region.

BE CAREFUL WITH WHAT WHY DID YOU TELL
ME THIS?

And off they went.

It was pitch dark (no head lamp!) and getting very cold, very quickly, but I had no other choice. I wore all my clothes (literally!) and waited in the dark. I could barely use my phone because I didn’t want to take my hands out of my pockets. It was the longest 20 minutes of my life. I felt that I was in a movie terror. A crime scene. A mountain lion’s dinning table. Every single sound in the mountains (and I was surrounded by them) caused a shiver down my spine. And I couldn’t even see it. Was it a mountain lion or just a leaf falling? Who knows.

Finally my trail angel arrived (omg thank you for coming back). When I said thank you so much she said it’s my pleasure Bruno, I said I was coming back for you, I came back the fastest as I could.

It was 10 o’clock already, one hour past hiker’s midnight. I didn’t have a place to sleep in town. All the inns and hotels were already closed, since usually they don’t get late night unannounced guests. I went to the city’s campground. I couldn’t find nobody to check-in (and pay) so I just entered, found a spot and set my tent. In the end I could book a tent spot online, so at least I could sleep without possibly being woken up at 6am by the campground patrol.

Before falling in deep sleep, I cooked water and mixed everything else that I had in a single meal. My spaghetti-couscous-olive-oil-peanut-butter was absolutely delicious!

Even though I was depleted, I couldn’t fall asleep. My mind wanted to think about all the bad things, all the risks, all the exhaustion. I put in my mind that I wouldn’t think about anything or make any plans. I put my headphones on and fell asleep almost instantly.

all_steps.name: Idyllwild - First Zero!
all_steps.description:
Day 10
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 179.4 (287km)

My first Zero! (a day where you hike zero miles)

It’s funny because you would think that on a zero you will rest. But in reality, a zero day is used to do all the city chores you can’t while your in the wild.

I woke up early as usual, but I was still very tired and very sleepy. My body was stiff from both the intensity of yesterday and the lack of stretching (usually I stretch before and after hiking and yesterday I skipped the latter). When I got up to use the bathroom, I realized that my socks and shoes were wet. And it was 4 degrees outside! Wet socks on, wet shoes on and here we go to start our zero day!

Idyllwild is such a cute town. There are plenty of places to have breakfast (by plenty I mean like five) and I decided to have a breakfast burrito 🌯! Oh breakfast burrito! An old favorite of mine! I decided to go to Mama’s Egg House 🤱🥚🏠!

And who do I meet there? Clara!! It was so so good to see a familiar face and catch up about the last days. She’s having a good time so far and also taking a zero. She actually hitched from PVC to resupply and buy micro spikes (good idea!) and is coming back there tomorrow to continue her hike. And we had the conversation over a proper freshly brewed coffee. Life is already getting better!

From there I came back to the campground to call Maike 💜, pack and go to the Ranger’s office to ask for a permit to enter and camp the San Jacinto Wilderness Area (I’ll explain why when I get at Big Bear Lake at mile 266). Mary, the ranger that signed my permit was the most adorable person and so enthusiastic about her job. It’s so good to be treated with so much care and attention. Thank you, Mary! You definitely made my day better!

From there I went to the gear shop to resupply and buy some additional equipment. I upgraded my water bladder (that I I use for filtering water) and added a nice elastic chord outside my backpack so I can hang things a little bit easier. Other than that, just the usual food/gas/electrolytes/snacks shopping. And I got a whole celery stalk as a gift! 

Finished with that, I went to a café to have another coffee and rest a bit before I could check-in into my room. There I run into Clara again, which was awesome to kill time. From there I checked in and got my room!

It seems that as soon as I entered my room, my backpack exploded everywhere! I went immediately to shower and wore my rain pants and jacket, so I could do laundry. The rest of my day was divided between laundry, cleaning my equipment (sleeping bag and tent), going to the supermarket, ordering a pizza (I ate it with a full bag of salad, I’m calling this pizzalata) and repacking everything again. All of a sudden it’s already 8 in the eventing and I’m almost ready to sleep. I lighted up the fireplace and before I could even enjoy it I was already dreaming 😴.

all_steps.name: My first nearo!
all_steps.description:
Day 11
Idyllwild to Strawberry Campground (mile 183.3)
PCT Miles: 3.9 (6.2km)
Total Miles: 183.3 (293.3km)

We call a day like today a nearo. It’s near zero.

For some reason I didn’t sleep well. Maybe my body rejected the idea of me sleeping in a king bed on my zero. To compensate that I had raspberry ice cream and pizza for breakfast. I actually bought the ice cream because I want to use the cup as a container for musli/granola! Let’s see if it works 🙃.

After breakfast I sent a message on the “Idyllwild Trail Angels” facebook group asking for a ride to the trailhead. One guy responded within one hour (thanks Leo!) saying the he would pick me up at the inn at 11 and drive me to the trailhead of Devil’s Slide, so I can continue the PCT from where I left. Sweet!

The difference between packing up in a room or in the campground is that in a room you’re never sure that you packed everything. In the campground, you just look back and make sure there’s nothing left behind.

In the meantime, Hanne (a girl from Belgium who started hiking together on the first day with Clara, Max and Marie/Mary) texted me because she also wanted to go to Devil’s Slide. That was awesome because I was not looking very forward to hike up the snow-covered trail alone. Everything worked perfectly and Leo also picked her up. I hiked most of my short day with her.

As soon as we started we met a legend from the PCT, SanJacJon. It’s a guy that voluntarily climbs up the San Jacinto Peak every week to report the current status of the track. I literally watched his video (from April 18th) this morning where he reported the conditions of the Fuller Ridge, the trail that I’ll hike tomorrow. As a matter of fact, I decided to hike it tomorrow and not today because of his report.

Since the Devil’s Slide (2.5 mile long, 1600 feet of elevation) is not part of the PCT, both the hike down two days ago and the hike up are not added to the total miles hiked 🥲. At least this time I could actually see the path and even though there was a lot of snow, both of us didn’t use the spikes. We took our time to hike steady and slowly. It was a beautiful hike, even though the fog decided to show up at some point.

After arriving at Saddle Junction (where the PCT continued) we kept hiking slow, following the path on the snow until we reached 9000 feet of altitude. Even though I’m carrying food for 7-8 days, I don’t need to carry more than one liter of water at a time, since water here up in the mountains is abundant because of all the snow melting, so the weight of my backpack is ok.

Around 4pm I arrived at my campsite. Hanne kept hiking for a few more miles. I pitched my tent, had an early dinner (Pad Thai) and now, 17:44, I’m already ready to sleep 😴.

PS: I had a hole on the phone pocket of my shorts. I have a tiny sewing kit 🪡 with me and I made a beautiful repair myself!

all_steps.name: Anatomy of a fall
all_steps.description:
Day 12
Strawberry Campground (mile 183.3) to mile 201.1
PCT Miles: 17.8 (28.5km)
Total Miles: 201.1 (321.8km)

I didn’t sleep well again, so I was a bit lazy in the morning (and also it was very cold). I left camp around 7:30 prepared for my day full of snow and ice 🧊.

After a few miles I already had to put my spikes on and I kept them on for at least four hours. In the beginning of the day it was easy to hike on the ice, because everything was kind of refrozen from the night. But as I advanced in the day (today was very sunny, gorgeous!), the ice and snow started to melt and everything became slippery. Hiking on slippery ice is such a mental process!

And it just takes one microsecond of distraction for something to go wrong. That was exactly what happened to me today.

At some point I had removed my spikes because the
snow was gone. After maybe 15-20 minutes, the snow was back on the trail and I decided to put the spikes back on (which is a tedious process because you have to find a place to sit, take off the backpack, etc). And I’m so happy that I did.

The trail was full of snow but it also was fully exposed to the sun. That made all the ice and snow very slushy, very not grippy. I can’t even remember how, but I stepped in a slippery part and in a fraction of a second I was sliding down a “gentle” slope. Gentle because it was not a cliff or anything, but it took me 5-6 seconds to be able to stop the fall. At the cost of my knuckles and one of my hiking poles. Nothing serious happened to me. Later I found out that all my three water bottles had fallen from my backpack during my own fall. What a morning! (you can watch me talking about the accident on the last video of this post.)

After I realized what had just happened I was a bit down (and thirsty). For the rest of the morning I hiked fully focused on the path, taking very cautious step after step. Around 1pm I arrived in this nice picnic area and stopped for lunch and to tape my knuckles. After this break, the snow and ice were really gone,l so no spikes were needed anymore. In fact, it became very sunny and warm and “desertic” again. I don’t think I’m going to see snow again for the next 500 miles. For the next four hours (12 miles) the path was much easier and downhill. I made camp at 6pm.

For the coming 4 days, until I’m in town again, my full water capacity is only 2 liters. Let’s hope that it’s going to be enough 🤞!

all_steps.name: Back to the desert 🏜️
all_steps.description:
Day 13
Mile 201.1 to Whitewater Preserve (mile 218.5)
PCT Miles: 17.4 (27.8km)
Total Miles: 218.5 (349.6km)

I’m definitely in the desert again.

I started walking around 7am, with a beautiful sunrise 🌄. This beautiful sunrise soon became unbearable heat with absolutely no shade to hide.

I had a water situation since I lost my 3 water bottles. Being in the desert again means caring about water consumption and refill. I was counting on a water cache that trail angels put under the bridge that intersects the I-10 highway. And thankfully the cache was there. I used the shade also to have lunch and camel up. 

4 miles after, my maps shows that there should be an office of a windmill company where they welcome PCT hikers! I went there and it’s pretty cool: they have sodas, snacks, water (and later I found out that inside another door they also have ice cream and clean flush toilets 🤩! Hikers paradise! I took 3 500ml water bottles, so now I have capacity of 3.5 liters.

The rest of the day was pretty much like the beginning: hiking in the desert (I was rattled at! I didn’t see the rattler, but you can hear in one of the videos the rattle), managing water consumption, trying (unsuccessfully) to hide from the sun.

At the end of the day, I decided to go a bit off trail to a place called Whitewater Preserve, that also welcome hikers. Such a nice place! One of the coolest places I’ve camped so far 🤙! And the best price ever: nada!

all_steps.name: Upstream
all_steps.description:
Day 14
Whitewater Preserve (mile 218.5) to mile 236.9
PCT Miles: 18.4 (29.4km)
Total Miles: 236.9 (379km)

You know your day will be awesome when it’s not even 6am and you’re already barefoot, crossing an ice cold stream. Silly me, taking out my shoes to cross the stream…

I learned yesterday that in 2023 a hurricane (Hillary) completely devastated this part of the PCT. In short, there’s one part of the PCT (around 10 miles) that is completely gone and in order to advance you have to hike upstream on a creek. Sounds like fun!

And it was actually fun. For the first 2-3 hours, but not the whole day. Today’s hike looked the same throughout the day: hiking uphill, on a very difficult and annoying terrain (rocks, rocks everywhere) and crossing a water stream back and forth for almost a hundred times! At least carrying water was not a problem today… 

Today was also the first day that I had the full rattlesnake experience: being rattled at, almost having a heart attack, and then seeing the monster looking at you as if it want to eat you alive. All of that with that rattle that sounds like a death sentence. At least, with rattlesnakes the theory works: just go back, give it some space and at some point it’ll go away. That’s exactly what happened 😮‍💨. I also saw another rattlesnake later, but that one was more chill (see picture).

After like 8 hours of hiking in the exact same scenario (11 hours total), I finally got out of the creek and finally rejoined the undamaged part of the PCT. In the end I found a very nice spot to camp tonight.

PS: my little toes look like chickpeas ready to be peeled 🫣!

all_steps.name: A normal day (finally!)
all_steps.description:
Day 15
Mile 236.9 to Arrastre Trail Camp (mile 256.2)
PCT Miles: 19.3 (30.9km)
Total Miles: 256.2 (409.9km)

After an exhausting day, I finally slept well. Weirdly I woke up not in the best mood ever. I left camp at 6:30 and took me a few hours to really get going. The day started with more hiking up the creek’s bed until finally I was on the trail for real. There were parts of tre trail that were destroyed and some bushwhacking and “make your own path” were necessary. It was kind of fun. If I wouldn’t be so tired from yesterday I would probably have enjoyed much much more.

The day was beautiful and because I was high in the mountains (above 8000 feet for most of the day) it was not so warm. There was even some ice/snow but they were perfectly manageable, no need for spikes and no falls!

Even though there was nothing particularly special (finally!), I love days like today. No stress, nothing scary, just walking, walking and walking 🚶‍♂️.

all_steps.name: Outbreak
all_steps.description:
Day 16
Arrastre Trail Camp (mile 256.2) to Big Bear City
PCT Miles: 9.9 (15.8km)
Total Miles: 266.1 (425.8km)

What a cold night! I think this was the first night that it was below freezing 🥶 brrrrr. Waking up at 5:30, getting out of my warm sleeping bag and unpitching the tent when it’s cold is so so difficult. The tent poles feel like ice bars in your hands. It was the first
morning so far that I started hiking with my puff jacket on (plus gloves and windbreaker).

It didn’t take long though for the sun to come up and for me so start peeling off my layers. At 7:30 or so I was already hiking on full desert mode.

The hiking day itself was pretty short and uneventful. At 10 I was already waiting for a trail angel (Kenny) to pick me up. I needed to resupply for the coming days and my initial plan was to take a zero tomorrow in Big Bear. Kenny brought me to his place, where he hosts hikers. Such a crazy place! There was freshly made breakfast (french toast 🍞, eggs 🍳 and chili potatoes 🌶️🥔! I also met some of people that I had been hiking with in the past days and some of the people that I met last night on camp. With one similarity between them all: they were all sick. And when I say sick, I mean *sick*.

One of the assumptions is that it could have been the water from the demoniac mission creek from the past days. It’s weird because everybody filters the water. I for sure drank from the creek at some point (although I don’t remember when or how much).

The other possibility would be a virus that’s infecting everyone. I found this quite fascinating since it seems that everybody got sick at the exact same time. BUT there’s this norovirus thing going on here in the US and the symptoms seem to match.

Also… the norovirus is waterborne and our filters don’t filter virus, only bacteria 🦠🤯.

We’re 13 people at Kenny’s Place and so far only 4 are not sick. Fingers crossed, knocking on wood!

In any case, during the day I went to resupply. I thought Big Bear would be cosy like Idyllwild, but it was more like a bigger town, bigger streets kind of vibe. I went to the gear shop and to the supermarket and fully resupplied for 5-6 days. Kenny, such a nice dude, drove me and other healthy hikers back and forth.

So, I decided that I won’t take a zero tomorrow. Physically I feel fine and I see no strong reason to stay here. Unless — fingers crossed, knocking on wood — I feel sick tonight.

all_steps.name: Surprisingly 20
all_steps.description:
Day 17
Big Bear City to mile 285.6
PCT Miles: 19.5 (31.2km)
Total Miles: 285.6 (457km)

If yesterday before bedtime Kenny’s house looked like a quarantine ward, this morning everybody was feeling much, much better. The day started slowly but soon we were making breakfast! Kenny made chili potatoes and sausages, Chilli Beans piloted the waffle machine, Google made scrambled eggs and Mermaid and me prepared a gigantic fruit salad!

I was the only one in the house that was not going to take a zero: because I was feeling fine yesterday, I had time to resupply and I was feeling physically very good, so there’s no need to take a zero. Kenny drove me back to the trail head around noon and I continued hiking north.

My plan was to hike 12-14 miles, but the trail was super simple and chill. The weather was also good, sunny but with lots of shade. I kept a good pace for more or less seven hours and ended up hiking almost 20 miles. On the way, I crossed paths with Max (the french dude whom I walked together on the first days)! We had a quick talk but both of us were on a mission to crush some miles. I finished my day a bit after 7, camping close to a water stream.

About the outbreak yesterday: it seems that nobody before yesterday got sick (and I don’t know today — I don’t have internet at the moment to check). To me it still sounds weird that it’s a virus. Nobody had fever and everybody was 90% fine after 24 hours. It looks more like poisoning or an intoxication of some sort. I was absolutely lucky to have skipped whatever part of the creek that was contaminated! This morning before I left Kenny’s, we heard stories about helicopters and ambulances having to rescue sick hikers on the trail!

Day 18
Mile 285.6 to mile 310.5
PCT Miles: 24.9 (39.8km)
Total Miles: 310.5 (496.8km)

I slept super good. I even overslept a bit and left camp around 7:30. Before leaving, I saw Hanne (a girl from Belgium who’s part of the first group I hiked with) and we talked a bit. She will hike the PCT only for 2 months, so she’s skipping some parts. She skipped Mission Creek so she didn’t get sick. I heard today that Clara (she’s +/- 2 days behind me) also got sick with the water 😞.

There were some river crossings today. Each crossing comes with its own challenges. Some you have to cross with your shoes, some it’s better to go barefoot. Sometimes you can find rocks and tree branches and somehow make your way to the other side without getting wet. Sometimes it’s better to use the hiking poles, sometimes it’s better to store them in the backpack. On every crossing you have to remember to make wise decisions.

Now that there’s not much elevation gain and water isn’t an issue, I’ve been able to hike a little bit faster.  Even though today for whatever reason I hiked a bit backwards by accident, I was able to fish the day with almost 25 miles. That’s a record for this trip 🏆!

When I arrived at where I intended to camp, all spots were taken. I had to keep walking a bit more and found a very solitary place for my tent. It’s super cool and the sound of the water is very loud here. Also, it’s winding a bit too much for my taste. Hopefully the wind won’t blow my tent away 🙏!

all_steps.name: Good hiking day 🥾👍
all_steps.description:
Day 19
Mile 310.5 to mile 332.3
PCT Miles: 21.8 (34.9km)
Total Miles: 332.3 (531.7km)

It was quite windy during the night and apparently it rained, because my tent and part of my backpack were wet in the morning. I didn’t see a thing, I slept like a baby.

The morning was beautiful and the hike was quite pleasant during the whole day. I had to do two river crossings, one barefoot and another with my shoes which made me hike with wet feet for half of the day. There wasn’t much elevation again and the landscape was pretty beautiful, specially in the afternoon, when the PCT went around a big lake.

The weather was quite good for most part of the day, except when all of a sudden some dark
clouds showed up. But in the end it was just some cold wind and after a while the sun appeared again.

I noticed that I’ve been eating much more than two weeks ago. I dare to say that I’m currently eating twice what I was eating before. This is a problem because of costs and weight carried. But we’ll think about this later. Tomorrow we feast! (tomorrow I’ll pass by a famous landmark of the PCT: the McDonalds at Cajon Pass)

all_steps.name: Meh’c Donald’s
all_steps.description:
Day 20
Mile 332.3 to mile 351.8
PCT Miles: 19.5 (31.2km)
Total Miles: 351.8 (562.9km)

What a beautiful morning! It was delightful to watch the sunrise 🌄 while packing up to start the day!

I was kind of excited about going to the Mc Donald’s  but the closer I got, the more I realized that I actually didn’t really feel like junk food. I heard that there was a “Fruit Dude” that sells big cups of fresh fruit nearby. My plan was to go there first and then to Mc Donald’s, so at least I had some healthy stuff on my stomach.

Unfortunately the Fruit Dude was not there (although the stand was), so I went for plan B and decided to eat a Mc-anything-veggie. Except that they didn’t have any veggie burgers, so I ended up ordering two big fries, a caramel sundae, coffee and ice tea. I devoured the fries and the sunday 🤤! Finally I had good internet so I could also facetime Maike 💜.

I was not very amused with my breakfast so far. There was a group of hikertrash chilling close to the Mc Donald’s and I joined them. From there I saw that the Fruit Dude was back to his stand!

Biggest fruit cup I’ve ever seen. I couldn’t finish it! It was so good to eat so much fresh fruit 🍉🥭🥥!

The next step of the day was to hike ten more miles (it had taken me 10 miles to get to Mc Donald’s) uphill and without water sources for the next 25 miles. Time to camel up and refill with 6.5 liters of free filtered water at Mc Donald’s! (this and the flush toilet were by far the best things I got at Mc Donald’s today.)

Refuelled with salt, sugar, caffeine, filtered water, vitamins and love I continued with my day. No surprises in the afternoon, just a continuous hike up carrying a lot of water. I made camp around 6pm and tomorrow I should arrive in town!

all_steps.name: Unmeltable Ice
all_steps.description:
Day 21
Mile 351.8 to Wrightwood
PCT Miles: 17.5 (28km)
Total Miles: 369.3 (590.9km)

I made a sightly miscalculation yesterday. I thought today would be a 10 miles day, but it was in reality 17.5 (instead of hiking until close to the next town, Wrightwood, I had to hike until the highway, past Wrightwood). The biggest problem with this miscalculations is the potential lack of food and water. In this case, I lacked both.

I only had about 3 liters for the whole day (I drink 1 liter every 4 or 5 miles) and I had no food other than 3 cliff bars. The cherry on top 🍒 was the fact that the trail today kept ascending until 8500 feet and for some obscure reason then snow and ice in this region don’t melt even if it’s crazy hot. Time for some ice/slush hiking and microspikes on!

A bit before 4pm I was finished and ready to hitch a ride to town. That didn’t take me much effort as I was offered two rides by two different people. Fun Fact, a hiker that hiked the PCT in 2021 and it was just section hiking this year, gave me a ride to my accommodation for the next two nights (tomorrow is a zero!)

I’ve just had a shower (my third on the PCT, after three weeks!) and I’m waiting for a ride to the pizza place to have my third pizza on the PCT. Maybe I should keep this tradition: for every shower on trail, I get myself a pizza! 🚿🍕👍

all_steps.name: Zero: Wrightwood
all_steps.description:
Day 22
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 369.3 (590.9km)

It’s zero day!

Yesterday in the evening the owner of this place that I’m staying for two nights offered me and the other guests (two other couples) to do laundry for us! This sounds like music to a thru-hiker (specially because there’s no public laundry in Wrightwood).

This morning I had pizza for breakfast (I ended up eating the same pizza for dinner yesterday, breakfast, lunch and dinner today) and headed to the town center (which is literally a street with 4-5 shops and a few bars and restaurants). I resupplied both at the supermarket and at the equipment shop and I also grabbed my new pair of shoes that I had ordered back in Big Bear. Same shoes, same color, half a size up. I’m calling them Two Goats.

Hiking-wise I feel super good. All my blisters are gone and I don’t feel any pain. I believe I’ve been eating the best I can, drinking properly and being careful regarding the sun. Because of that I’ll try to have a bit more mileage without resupplying for the coming days/weeks. Tomorrow I leave with food for eight days! I’m hoping water won’t be much of a problem so I can carry less water and balance the weight out.

After a lot of thoughts and considerations, tomorrow I’ll do an alternate road trail instead of climbing up to Mount Baden-Powell. I chose that because I’m fully loaded (with snacks and supplies 🎶) and I would need to carry a lot of water. It’s around 9400 feet and it’s all steep and icy, up and down. I’m fine with road walk!

Another reason I chose to road walk is that I want to finally hike listening to music. So far, I haven’t hiked a single minute listening to music, mostly so I could be aware of rattlesnakes. This morning, going back and forth to the town center, I could listen to music and it felt super good (thanks for Lemonade, Tessa!). I want to do the same tomorrow.

A side effect of this decision is that I will carry my new shoes but I’ll walk on my old shoes: they’re currently very not-grippy but this is not a problem for road walk. As soon as I go back to the trail I’ll swap them (and eventually discard my old pair of shoes). I also decided that I’m not mailing forward any equipment (like the micro spikes — they won’t be necessary until mile ~700). I’ll just carry everything.

The place I’m staying is kind of a day spa with sauna and massages upon request. I had a very well deserved one hour full body massage this afternoon and it was excellent! I’ve also soaked my feet in epsom salt 🧂 and it’s amazing how my feet don’t look like they’ve been hiking non-stop for three weeks! ✨🦶✨

Feeling well-rested and motivated for the coming days!

all_steps.name: Road walk
all_steps.description:
Day 23
Wrightwood to mile 392.2
PCT Miles: 22.9 (36.6km)
Total Miles: 392.2 (627.5km)

Knowing it would be almost a whole day of road walk, I already stowed my hiking poles and put my headphones on since the beginning of the day. It was a bit of s late start (around 10am) because I had to wait to get a ride from my host. But as soon as I was hiking again I had a very good day enjoying the walk (even being on asphalt), with no need to be always checking the map and without having to pay so much attention regarding snakes 🐍 or anything, really. For the first half of the day, the road was closed for cars. For the second half, I saw 4 or 5 cars, max. It was super chill and the day just passed by 🎶🎶.

My backpack is a bit too heavy. I bought food at the supermarket that is not freeze dried and therefore it weight much more. Tonight I’m having two of those for dinner, so it’s almost 600g less to carry!

Day 24
Buckhorn Campground (mile 392.2) to mile 418.4
PCT Miles: 26.2 (41.9km)
Total Miles: 418.4 (669.4km)

When you hike long distances there are always days that go by and nothing extraordinary happen, specially when you get used to the logistics of hiking. Days like today: the sun was shining, it started with an ascent and later a decent. I had to make sure to collect water at the right sources and manage my consumption, I ate five cliffs bar during the day and had watermelon electronola for lunch. I had an encounter with a snake. Late afternoon there was a glimpse of a storm but it was soon gone and the sun was back. At the end of the day I hiked a marathon. 

Just a normal hiking day 😊!

all_steps.name: Trail Magic 🪄
all_steps.description:
Day 25
Mile 418.4 to LA Camping
PCT Miles: 25.9 (41.4km)
Total Miles: 444.3 (710.9km)

Last night I camped in a kind of sketchy place, close to some power lines in a construction site. Before 6am today I had already left “camp” and started hiking.

For the first 3/4 of the day, the pattern from yesterday repeated: going up and going down, managing water consumption, taking regular pauses for snacks. The days have been warm but bearable 🐻 the water sources frequent enough. Not much to tell until I was about 4 miles from camp. I was feeling good, all my blisters are healed, the massage and the zero surely helped my body to rest and recover.

I was already planning to have a break for a snack, drink water and rest a bit before the last two hiking hours of the day when I saw a sign 🪧 for a hiker’s party happening today with free food and drinks!

That was exactly it: a big table with all kinds of snacks plus sandwiches and burritos. Also cold beer, soda and gatorade! I don’t know how, I don’t know why, but everything for free.

I spend 45 minutes eating apple, m&ms, trail mix, nuts, all types of cookies, celery, carrots, two cliff bars, doritos, raisins and drinking an ice cold orange gatorade!

Everything was good but as it usually happens with me in parties, I soon got bored and decided to continue hiking. I thanked the trail angels and kept going. Even with the party pause, it was still around 5pm after I hiked the last 4 miles that I had planned for today. That’s a bit too early to stop hiking so I kept pushing for 2 more hours and ended up at a proper camping place. They have showers, toilets and even have towels for the PCT hikers! So an unexpected and unplanned shower happened!

I was about to write that the score now is 4 showers vs 3 pizzas, but someone here at the camping site just offered me more than half of a vegetarian pizza they couldn’t handle. So I guess the score now is tied in 4 showers and 4 pizzas 😊!

all_steps.name: All you can eat 🇲🇽
all_steps.description:
Day 26
LA Camping (mile 444.3) to mile 465.6
PCT Miles: 21.3 (34.1km)
Total Miles: 465.6 (745km)

Taking full advantage of having access to running water and a flush toilet, I had a very slow morning. I also wanted to check the general store that opened at 8am: because I got so much food for free yesterday, I thought about extending my next resupply for three more days. For that, though, I needed to find food for one more day either at this store or in 10 miles in a tiny town called Agua Dulce.

The general store was very unimpressive. I bought 2 frozen burritos for breakfast (they had a microwave) and 4 snickers. They also had free coffee for hikers!

Before leaving the campground I swapped my shoes and now I’m officially on my second pair, Two Goats ✌️🐐. It’s very impressive how a new pair of shoes make all the difference. The size (half a size up from my previous one) is perfect.

I arrived at Agua Dulce at 1:30pm and I was starving. Because of the double burrito 🌯🌯 in the morning I didn’t snack anything for 4 hours, but now I was very hungry. There was a Mexican restaurant literally on the PCT. If I had lunch here then I could have snacks for dinner and my food problem regarding the resupply would be solved!

I didn’t realize, but today is Mother’s day here in the US (in Brazil too!). At the Mexican restaurant they were having a all you can eat buffet. Yes, that’s right. Me, a starving hiker, in a all you can eat mexican buffet.

My first plate had 8 quesadillas on it. Plus rice, and beans and peppers and eggs with cheese. I don’t remember the last time I ate so much in a single meal. And that was only the first plate.

I was already fine after eating the first plate, but why not having a second? They had salads and fruits and waffles (?!) and sweets… I ended up having four plates and 1.5 liter of iced tea.

Hiking after that meal in the desert at 30 degrees uphill was an experience that I recommend to anyone. For the first two hours after having lunch I couldn’t even drink water, so full I was. But everything was under control and now that I’m in my tent writing this and seeing in retrospect, I think it was good that I ate a generous amount 😁. I didn’t need to eat dinner so my food is perfect to hike for the next 100 miles without resupplying!

Another snake encounter, some rock views, tunnels and art were also part of this busy day 😊!

all_steps.name: Uninvited guests
all_steps.description:
Day 27
Mile 465.6 to mile 488.2
PCT Miles: 22.6 (36.2km)
Total Miles: 488.2 (781.1km)

Something that I knew that inevitably was going to happen (and for sure will happen again), but you always hope that it just doesn’t happen: I had my tent invaded by rodents during the night!

I only found out this morning, because of the huge hole on the net of my tent and also on my food bag. Apparently they went for trail mix, not much of a loss, but this is definitely not the best way to start the day.

I was telling this story later in the day while having lunch with Lizard, Spider and Peaches 🦎🕷️🍑 (the only three people that i’ve seen during the whole day) and Lizard said that two nights ago she had a mice in her sleeping bag! I prefer a thousand times to share my food from time to time with the little thieves. From now on my food bag stays outside the tent. At least next time my tent doesn’t end up with another hole ⛺️🕳️ .

I have 78 miles between me and my next resupply (in Tehachapi) and I have just enough food for 4 days (and 3 nights). I’ll try to do big miles in the coming 3 days so I can arrive in Tehachapi on Friday as early as possible and eat in town.

all_steps.name: By the book 📕
all_steps.description:
Day 28
Mile 488.2 to mile 511.0
PCT Miles: 22.8 (36.5km)
Total Miles: 511 (817.6km)

Waking up at 5:30, leaving camp before 6, short and smart pauses. 10 before 10. Carrying just enough water to the next source.

Today I played the PCT by the book!

Yesterday, I forgot to mention: I provisionally fixed my tent (and my food bag) with the same tape I used to do bandages. When I get in town I’ll try to buy some proper tape.

I only saw two hikers (a couple) today during the whole day. When I arrived at the camping spot that I intended to spend the night though, there were more than 20 people camping there! Some of them are cowboy camping (camping without a tent, only sleeping mat and bag) because there’s not enough space. I found a little spot that literally only fits my tent (without the rain cover) further down the trail. Let’s see how it goes!

all_steps.name: Heat Endurance
all_steps.description:
Day 29
Mile 511.0 to mile 535.0
PCT Miles: 24 (38.4km)
Total Miles: 535 (856km)

The night was a success, I slept very well, no condensation on my sleeping bag and no attack to the food bag! Great!

The morning was no different. Before 6 I had left camp already and started the day on a very calm morning hike. The weather was good, the wind was good, the path was mellow. I looked ahead at the map and it seemed that the whole day would be a big flat walk. I like flat walks! Time for some music!

The problem with this specific flat walk is that it was in the middle of the Mojave desert with absolutely no shade. After 10am, what was a “good weather” became extreme heat reflected back to your body by the sand. There were specific places where I needed to get water to make sure I had enough to keep me hydrated.

Since it was a flat walk, I stowed my poles and used my umbrella to protect me from the sun. It’s the first time I use the umbrella like this and it worked better than I expected. In the end it wasn’t an easy hike, but given my early start time and good cadence walking on the flat, I arrived at camp, 24 miles later, before 5pm. Time to slowly stretch, collect and filter water, pitch the tent, cook dinner, brush my teeth, recharge electronics, plan for tomorrow and sleep 😴 .

all_steps.name: Wind farm 🌬️
all_steps.description:
Day 30
Mile 535.0 to mile 562.0
PCT Miles: 27 (43.2km)
Total Miles: 562 (899km)

I camped in a big camping area last night and I found it strange that it was so empty (there was just one couple other than me). I got a very nice spot protected from the wind and close to the water!

Soon after midnight people started to arrive 🤨 and then everything made sense: Most hikers are choosing to hike very early in the morning and/or late afternoon/evening to avoid the heat. The aqueduct seems to be a known rough part of the trail (for those who don’t have an umbrella ☂️😉).

I found out that yesterday I entered a wind farm territory that’s open for PCT hikers. I had never heard this term before, but whoever decided to build a wind farm here had a very good idea. It winds a lot.

It was like on the first days of the PCT where it’s not only sunny, hot and shadeless but it’s also dry and the hot wind sucks all the moisture from you. You just sweat and feel thirsty all the time. And usually when you drink, the water it’s lukewarm 🙃.

At mile 549 there was such a cool spot maintained by a trail angel that looks like a bar, with chairs 🪑, a library 📚 with a few games and books, cookies and ramen (!) and most importantly: water. I made my lunch break there and met a few other hikers: Hammer, Chad, Red Lentils and No Map.

Nothing changed for the afternoon: hot, windy and dry. I was literally in the middle of hundreds of wind turbines (or whatever these are called). 

The highlight of the day happened 4 miles before my final campsite. Right before a road crossing, this man was sitting in a camp chair by his truck and he offered me a cold gatorade (omg thanks) and we chatted a bit. He, Magicman, does this for nine years: he goes driving from Campo (where the PCT starts) to Oregon stopping here and there for a few days to offer cold drinks to PCT hikers. He stands the freaking whole day by his car where he has giant coolers full of cold drinks and he gives them for free to random stranger PCT hikers because he likes it. He never hiked the PCT himself and he doesn’t accept any kind of donation.

I’m camping tonight in the middle of the wind farm hiding from the wind behind a juniper (?) tree. Now that I constantly now where North is, I know that the wind is coming from West and North-West so I positioned my tent accordingly to be more protected from the wind. I’m feeling like I’m the smartest person alive! But I must say that the wind is quite strong and my tent is unfortunately shaking much more than I wanted.

—

Thank you everyone who has been following (and liking and commenting!) my adventure here on Polarsteps for one month already!!! It’s been a real pleasure to share my days and to receive your energy back! Thank you!

all_steps.name: Tehachapi
all_steps.description:
Day 31
Mile 562.0 to mile 566.5
PCT Miles: 4.5 (7.2km)
Total Miles: 566.5 (906.4km)

I woke up this morning under an impressive wind gust. My tent was shaking but thankfully it held up very well. Time to pack and walk the last 5 miles to town! It’s a Nearo!

I had left in my food bag only two cliff bars and I had no water. It’s so much more comfortable hiking with less weight. You feel like you’re flying 🕊️!

When I arrived at the highway 🛣️ that brings you to Tehachapi, I had no idea 🤷 what to do. Obviously I couldn’t try to hitch on the highway, so I sat on an area that seemed that cars could stop and tried to text trail angels from a list that I had seen a few miles back.

After 20 minutes or so, this truck comes from
Tehachapi, stops close to where I was and drops off two PCT hikers. I asked hey are you going back to Tehachapi? The driver replied yeah, I sure am! Can you give me a ride? Of course!

Unfortunately I don’t remember the name of the driver. Before going to Tehachapi he had to stop at the “Dump” which is a crazy humongous place where people dump absolutely all kinds of trash. He had some bags of grass from his lawn mowing that needed to be dumped there.

After that he dropped me at Walmart and refused to take any money for gas. I was coming this way already, he said. Awesome! It was not even 10am and I was already in town. Time to start resupplying!

Walmart was 15 minutes walk from the hotel that I chose to spend the night (the one with free warm breakfast). So after buying 80% of my resupply for the next seven days, I came to the hotel and chilled there (while recharging all my electronics which for the first time in this trip were all depleted). At 12:00 I had lavash wrap 🌯 and fries 🍟 and a delicious baklava from a mediterranean restaurant close by. I could check in early at the hotel at 13:00 and could finally take a shower 🧼!

The rest of the day was divided into doing the usual town duties: laundry (even though I believe my yellow sun hoodie will never look not dirty again. The picture is *after* it was washed!), duct taping my tent, food bag and my shorts 🩳 (hopefully it will work better than my stitches 🪡), going to the sports shop to buy more food and back to walmart once more to buy vegetables for dinner and other resupply items like toothpaste and tissues.

Tomorrow I start my last stretch in the desert 🌵! I’m hoping to hike the next 140 miles in seven days 🤞.

all_steps.name: Last week in the desert 🐪
all_steps.description:
Day 32
Tehachapi to mile 587.5
PCT Miles: 21 (33.6km)
Total Miles: 587.5 (940km)

This morning I spent two hours having breakfast at the hotel. Granola, waffles, bagels, muffins, scrambled eggs, juices and coffee. I was weirdly proud on how much I could eat without feeling full.

Very conveniently there’s a bus 🚌 to the trailhead where I left off. Precisely on time, at 9:30 🕤 it arrived and 20 minutes later I was hiking the PCT. Even better, the ride was free 🆓!

The first eight miles would be an ascent and the next water source was in 16 miles. Besides food for seven days, I was carrying 3 liters of water plus 2 cans of nonalcoholic beer (leftovers from yesterday). It was not a bad idea to have kind-of-cold beer for the first two hydration stops of the day.

Miraculously, hiking uphill under the sun wasn’t so bad because of the strong wind. Maybe a bit annoying but at least not so exhausting. I was in good mood, feeling rested, so the day just flew by.

Sixteen miles later, at the water source, I checked and the next water would be in 20 miles! That means packing 5 liters of water. I decided to have dinner at the water source, so I wouldn’t need to use water to cook later at camp. I cooked a bag of dehydrated mashed potatoes that is meant for 8 portions. After cooked, it weighed about 1.2kg. One point two kilos of food for dinner. And I was not even so full after that. Crazy!

I kept walking for 5 more miles until I found a nice campsite where other 4-5 people are also camping. Since I didn’t have to cook, I used my time to have a good stretch. It’s now 20:52, only 8 minutes for hiker’s midnight! 😴😴😴

all_steps.name: Low morning 🪫
all_steps.description:
Day 33
Mile 587.5 to mile 613.2
PCT Miles: 25.7 (41.1km)
Total Miles: 613.2 (981.1km)

Usually I’m highly productive in the morning regarding making some miles. I’ve done a fair amount of 10 before 10s and usually I hike for 6-7 hours (around 15 miles) before taking a break for lunch. Then in the afternoon I go with the flow, just hiking until I find a good place to camp (around 7pm).

Today was completely the opposite.

It was a tough morning. I was carrying 4 liters of water (and my backpack is still full of food). The first water source was in 16 miles. It felt to me that it took forever for these miles to pass.

But eventually they did. I’m back in the mountains so there’s a lot of elevation, which disguises a bit the effort to hike a mile. The full backpack seems to weight three times more when you’re hiking uphill.

When I arrived at the water source (a pipe coming out of nowhere), I took a longer break than usual. I had lunch, cameled up (drink a lot of water) and chatted a bit with Aragorn (danish, father of 3, quit his job and is doing the PCT) and Dust (german, attempted last year but gave up because of the high amount of snow. Came back this year to finish what he started). These weird names, by the way, are “trail names”. I’ll talk about trail names in a post soon.

Taking a longer break (also it took a long time to filter the not-so-clean water) recharged my batteries a bit. I was planning to do around 21 miles today, but I decided to keep hiking for 4 miles more. Hiking in the afternoon was much more pleasant (and flat) so in the end it turned out to be a good day 🙃.

all_steps.name: Two water caches
all_steps.description:
Day 34
Mile 613.2 to mile 639.6
PCT Miles: 26.4 (42.2km)
Total Miles: 639.6 (1023.4km)

Beautiful morning! I left camp before 6am and the sun was already out. It’s very easy to observe that the sun is rising earlier and earlier.

Today was an interesting day in the sense that, since yesterday, the next two water sources (that provide water for ~40 miles) are two caches maintained by a trail angel 👼. I have no idea what hikers would do without those water caches.

During the night the winds were crazy. Surprisingly in the morning it was just a breeze but it picked up in the afternoon and there were some strong gusts that were a little bit scary. I really hope this wind thing is something from this region and that in the Sierra things will be calmer

I was feeling much more energized than yesterday and hiked in a very good pace, even though there were quite some uphills. As I eat, the backpack is becoming lighter. Also I realized that if I keep the daily mileage around 24 miles instead of 20, I can arrive in Kennedy Meadows South (the official end of the desert and beginning of the Sierra) one day earlier than I planned. I did well yesterday and did well today, so things are on track. For tomorrow I’ll have to hike at least 25 miles because of water reasons. Good chances that I arrive in KMS on Thursday instead of Friday 🏃🏻‍♂️!

I only saw 6 people today and it was the first time I saw every single one of them. So far from all the hikers I encountered since Tehachapi, I’m the only one who’s bringing food to go straight to KMS. The other option — that seems preferred by the others — is to hike once more to some town and resupply. I’m happy that I’m going in one go.

all_steps.name: Chezwick 🪨🚬
all_steps.description:
Day 35
Mile 639.6 to mile 667.7
PCT Miles: 28.1 (45km)
Total Miles: 667.7(1068.8km)

It was a cold and windy night but I slept very well. So well that I woke up after 6 and didn’t leave camp until 6:40, which usually is not ideal.

It turned out though that after a few steps I stop for a quick chat with this hiker who was sitting on a rock smoking a cigarette. Chezwick is his name. He started the PCT on May 2nd (!) and is doing an average of 35 miles per day. He finishes his cigarette and we hike together for the whole morning, around 12 miles for a quick lunch break. He eats cold soaked something (maybe knorr pasta?) with a lot of olive oil and SPAM 🤢. I eat a double cheese double peanut butter pita bread 😋.

This is the fourth time Chezwick is doing the PCT. He finished it three times already and he wants to finish this time in less than 80 days. Then, he will attempt to, before the end of the year, thru-hike both the CDT (Continental Divide Trail) and the AT (Appalachian Trail) and aim to beat the record of the fastest self-supported triple-crowner in a single calendar year! (self-supported: no assistance from friends or family; triple-crowner: someone who thru-hikes the AT, CDT and PCT)
