The trail this morning was fine, with some snow patches here and there, but nothing sketchy. We crossed paths with quite a few day hikers and chatted with most of them, as our mood was elevated. The highlight of the short day was to hike through a ski station! It’s so interesting to see ski lifts, gondolas and the pistes themselves all without snow. We actually went down (waking) one stretch of a blue piste!

We were a bit hungry when we arrived at the parking lot where we should try to hitch, so we sat down and started to eat some of our snacks and observe the movement. Hitching on a trailhead parking lot should be relatively easy: there’s not a lot of “traffic” but people are usually friendly and willing to give a hike to the next town after they had a pleasant hike themselves and are usually in good mood.

While still munching our food, we saw two guys coming back from the trail to their cars. They had no backpacks and seemed pretty chill. For a split second I thought about letting the laziness take control and ignore them, but I was looking forward to a breakfast burrito, so I went to them and asked “hey good morning. Are you guys by any chance going to Truckee? Could you give us a ride?” Double yes as an answer and we had a ride on our first try!!

They were Dion and Nick, from Australia and New Zealand, and they’re in the US traveling around and visiting some nice spots. They were staying in Truckee for the night so it wasn’t a problem at all first them to bring us. We talked a bit about hiking and the PCT and in 20 minutes we were in town, ready to devour our food and cold drinks!

After lunch we had another mission: find a way to go to our Airbnb which was in a ski resort, 12 miles away. Google Maps told us they there should be a bus that could bring us somewhere nearby our place. We walked a bit to the bus stop 🚏 and literally one minute later a car stopped for us “hey, do you guys want a ride?”. We couldn’t believe our eyes and ears!

Dave, the driver, was a local who also hikes and has hiked the PCT. He said he understands how helpful these rides are and that he always tries to give rides when he can. We talked a bit about hiking (as always) but also music and Europe. It was a pleasant 20 minutes hike to our Airbnb.

We had to wait a bit outside for our checkin time but afterwards everything went well: the wonders of flush toilet and a warm shower cannot be stated enough! It was our first shower since Sunday! Maike seemed really impressed with the dirtiness of her feet 😆.

For the rest of the day we chilled, of course. We finally had time to catch up with everything online, listen to some music and do nothing. Our friends Chris and Jessica arrived late in the evening (we were sleeping already) and tomorrow we take an adventurous zero!

all_steps.name: Rafting on the Truckee River
all_steps.description:
Day 74
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

Today marks the first day of my one week vacation from the PCT! I will be taking seven zeroes in a row to enjoy the company and opportunity to see my friends Chris and Jessica and also, of course, spend some chill time with Maike. And what better way of starting this week off other than grabbing drinks, a cooler, snacks and go rafting with your friends!?

We spent our morning paddling along the Truckee River, enjoying the good weather. Maike and me even took an (intentional) dip into the water 💧. After 3-4 hours of what we called “american rafting” (slowly going down the river with a cooler full of drinks and snacks in the middle of the raft) we arrived at the end of our adventure and took a bus back to the starting point. 

After having pizzas for lunch with an awesome view from the Tahoe Lake, we returned to our Airbnb and rested until the evening, when we made burgers on the grill and played games!

all_steps.name: Trail Angeling 😇
all_steps.description:
Day 75
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

Even before I started the PCT, there was one thing that I always wanted to do whenever I had a break from hiking: be a trail angel! Today sounded like the perfect day to do so! Of course Maike, Chris and Jessica were onboard!

Here was our plan: yesterday we bought some cookies 🍪 , gatorades and fresh fruits (🍎, 🍌, 🍒, 🍇) to bring today to the same trailhead where me and Maike finished our section together last Friday. The idea was to stay there and offer a refreshment to any PCT hiker that showed up on the parking lot.

So, after we checked out we drove to the trailhead’s parking lot, put all the food on a wood bench that we found and waited there for hikers. We stayed for a few minutes and nobody showed up. We had agreed that we would spend maybe 1-2 hours there and I was hoping to see at least 4-5 hikers in this timeframe.

I was feeling a little bit frustrated to see nobody so I decided to walk a bit to the actual trail and see if I could find someone coming. And then I saw something that I was not expecting at all!

A few meters down the road, I saw a couple setting up this gazebo, like if they were setting up a small gathering area. As soon as they saw me, the woman excitedly asked me: are you a PCT hiker? 

It turned out that this couple were hikers from the Class of 2021 and they lived close to the trail nowadays and they do some trail magic every now and then. They were setting up this space this morning with shade, chairs, drinks and making hot dogs for the thru-hikers! I explained my situation (that I’m indeed a PCT thru-hiker but I was taking a week off and that I was there with my friends to do some trail magic ourselves as well). Can we all join you guys? I asked. OF COURSE they replied in unison and a few moments later we brought our things and combined our trail magic together!

We stayed for probably two hours and had an absolutely great time. We met Pain Perdu and her boyfriend, Space Case, Sharkbait, Rosie, Koda (a czech girl that I met at Scout and Frodo, before I started the PCT!), Helène, Cashew (one of the dogs) and more people that I don’t remember the names. It felt so good to be able to give a little back to my fellow hikers. We left the place with our spirits elevated and empty coolers! We super happy that everything went better than we planned!

Before driving back to San Jose we chilled a bit at the Doner River’s riverside. I was feeling over the moon with this amazing experience that we had today!

Tomorrow me and Maike will be going to San Francisco to be tourists for a few days. The plan is for her to drive me back next saturday to the same trailhead of today so I can continue my hike keeping a continuous foot path). But until then, I’m using the fact that I’m a bit ahead of schedule to take some well deserved vacations from the PCT 😎!

all_steps.name: Biking the Golden Gate Bridge 🌉
all_steps.description:
Day 76
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

Waking up just to fall back asleep again is something that I haven’t done a lot these past two months and I certainly want to change that this week! So, this is exactly how the morning started!

After having a slow breakfast, we packed our tiny and light bags (no food carry, no sleeping bags, no bear canister!) and went to the station to get our train to San Francisco. One and a half hour later, we arrived (it’s crazy how cars and trains are faster than walking…).

We were able to check in early at our hostel, which is always good. From there we walked (uphill!) to Fisherman’s Wharf and the Marina, where we rented bikes to cross the Golden Gate Bridge 🌉 and go to Sausalito. The day was sunny, bright, clear and warm and the bike ride was very pleasant. In Sausalito we had burgers 🍔 and salad 🥗 for lunch, ice creams 🍦 and coffees ☕️ for dessert and enjoyed some chill time until late afternoon, when we got the ferry ⛴️ back to San Francisco. After returning the bikes we walked back to our hostel. We were able to enjoy a beautiful sunset on the way 🌇!

all_steps.name: Castro 🏳️‍🌈
all_steps.description:
Day 77
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

After having a not so fulfilling breakfast at the hostel (toast and jam) we took the trolley 🚃 to Castro where we would have a free walking tour and learn more about the history of this wonderful neighborhood.

Robert, our guide, having lived for decades in Castro himself, was very knowledgeable and insightful and we learned so much about how Castro came to be this epicenter of the
LGTQ community. Totally recommend the walking tour with him!

We were starving by the time we stopped for lunch at Cafe Mystique (our guide’s suggestion) with another german tour attendee around 2pm. From there we had a coffee and brigadeiros at Café de Casa. 

We slowly walked all the way back to the hostel where we just chilled for the rest of the afternoon. I watched Brazil vs. Colombia for Copa America and later we watched Mrs. Doubtfire at the hostel’s movie night!

all_steps.name: Last day in San Francisco
all_steps.description:
Day 78
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

I really can get used to waking up at 8 and not at 5 😬! After having a coffee and sandwiches at Beanstalk Cafe we walked to Yerba Buena Center for the Arts to visit a (free!) exhibition from Nick Dong. It had some crazy immersive artworks made either lights and mirrors. I really enjoyed it!

From there we walked to Embarcadero and stopped for lunch on the way. In between walking and occasional coffees, we had a very chill afternoon.

We took the train back to San Jose where Jessica and Chris picked us up and the four of us went out for dinner. After eating we realized that today we had breakfast, lunch AND dinner, something that hadn’t happened in a while! (and we also noticed that I ate my food and half of Maike’s food in every single meal today 😅😋)

all_steps.name: Independence Day 🇺🇸
all_steps.description:
Day 79
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

We wanted to do something very American on Independence Day but the 40°C day made us decide to stay home and enjoy some air conditioning. In fact, Chris and Jessica invited a few Brazilians (including children and dogs 🥰) for lunch and we made lasagnas for everybody!

For my surprise, some of the guests were former colleagues of mine back in Brazil and it was really cool to see and chat with them after so many years.

I don’t remember the last time I ate so much. During the day I had probably 5 liters of beer, lasagna, brownies, tiramisu, Melona ice cream and all the snacks that I could find. This week I’ve been doing a very good job at fattening up (I lost 8 kilos since I started the PCT and I really needed to gain some of the weight back).

(Un)fortunately I completely forgot to take pictures. I see that as a good sign 😊. I had a lot of fun today!

(It was so hot today that the thermostat couldn’t keep up and it was complaining that it had been trying to cool down the house for a few hours and the temperature was only going up 🥵)

all_steps.name: Getting ready to return to the PCT
all_steps.display_name: Getting ready to return to the PCT
all_steps.description:
Day 80
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

Another heat wave day, another day spent mostly inside.

Today I finally started resupplying and re-equipping to restart the PCT. Tomorrow I get back on trail for a new chapter on my thru-hike!

Since I’m done with the Sierra section (arguably the most difficult part of the whole trail) my plan for the next weeks is to increase my daily mileage and also the number of days that I spend on trail without resupplying. For the first time, I’m sending a resupply package ahead, since I’ll try to stop in towns and take as few zeroes as I can from now on. My next two hiking stretches should take 8-9 days each and I’m relying solely on my package 📦 for the next resupply (which will be in the middle of nowhere).

In the evening we went to downtown San Jose to enjoy some live music and to say goodbye to the best hosts I could have wished for: Chris and Jessica, thank you so much for all the support and everything you two have done for me in the past days (weeks). It was absolutely awesome to see you both and spend some good time together. I’m really grateful to have had the chance to use your place as part of my adventure! Thank you so much 💜🫶!

all_steps.name: Not exactly as planned
all_steps.description:
Day 81
PCT Miles: 0
Total Miles: 1154.5 (1847.2km)

“It could be worse!” — that was today’s motto.

I can count on one hand the days that I put an alarm to wake up during the PCT. Today, unfortunately, was one of them. Our plan was to pick up a car that we rented from someone using an app at 7am, so we woke up at 5:30 to finish packing. From there we would drive to Truckee and arrive before 2pm to post my resupply package before I restarted from the trailhead me and Maike ended at two weeks ago. From there Maike would return her rented bear canister in South Lake Tahoe and return to San Jose in the afternoon. 

This was the actual course of events:

We woke up, finished packing and said goodbye to our hosts. We took an Uber to pick-up the car (carrying all our stuff) and were there at 7am sharp. We waited for one hour and nobody showed up, so we canceled the car. Jessica picked us up and we went to a rental car company (in the meanwhile I reserved one car online to speed up the process). The guy behind the counter said that he was cancelling all the reservations for today because they had no cars available 🤷🏻‍♂️ . It was already 11am and we were still in San Jose (and it was getting warmer).

We tried the app one more time. The only car available was a Fiat 500 with a pick-up time at 4pm. We booked and called the owner to ask if we could do an early pick up. He said we could pick the car up in one hour, so we went to the Post Office in San Jose to send my resupply box (that I will hopefully receive in 9 days) and from there to pick-up the 500. Everything went smoothly and we finally had a car! Time to drive east and think about the plan B, since it was too late to restart the PCT today still.

New plan: we drive to South Lake Tahoe, deliver the bear canister somehow (the place where we rented closed at 4, we would arrive around 7), sleep somewhere in SLT (because Truckee is too expensive and it would be too much to drive today) and tomorrow early morning we drive ~1h30min to the trailhead.

On our way to SLT we saw smoke from a fire in a forest close by. I counted at least 5 airplanes/helicopters carrying buckets of water to control the fire. I’m not necessarily excited to be hiking into the wildfire season now. Today was the fourth day in a row with temperatures over 35°C. Our 500 was also struggling to keep the air inside cool while going up more than 7000ft in elevation gain.

Since we couldn’t actually return the bear canister, we hid it close to the ranger station (where we rented it) and tomorrow we’ll give them a call to check if they found it. From there we had a quick drive to our hotel (that we booked on our way here) and tomorrow we’re trying to leave to the trailhead at 7 and restart the bike at 9 or 10 latest. And then, 8-9 days of hiking with one focus: crush miles! (and escape the wildfires)

all_steps.name: Back to the PCT!
all_steps.description:
Day 82
Mile 1154.5 to mile 1174.7
PCT Miles: 20.2 (32.3km)
Total Miles: 1174.7 (1879.5km)

We woke up and enjoyed our last breakfast together for at least two months 🥺💜. We started driving a bit before 8am and at 10:30 I was saying goodbye to Maike and taking my first steps on the PCT since more than a week. It felt a bit bittersweet... I had an amazing time with Maike, both on trail and on my time off and to be very very honest I feel a bit demotivated with the PCT (and I blame the mosquitoes). But I have a plan to cheer me up.

I want to finish the PCT as soon as I can. Starting tomorrow, I’ll try to push a marathon per day. More than that, I will do longer stretches on trail before resupplying and I plan to take less zeroes. For this first stretch coming back to the PCT, I want to do 220 miles in 8.5 days. I started today (20 miles down!) and I want (need) to arrive by Monday before the post office closes (4pm) to grab my resupply box 📦. Then, I want to go back to trail on the same day and start a new 9 days stretch. Let’s see how this goes!

The first three or four hours hiking were very busy. It’s Sunday and there were a lot of day hikers and climbers (!) on or around the trail. But slowly it started to become less common to see people and after 3pm I didn’t see anybody for the rest of the day.

Although it was warm, I enjoyed the hiking day. Unfortunately the mosquitoes did show up but they gave a break around dinner time, so it wasn’t so bad. 

I must say that I’m becoming a bit scared of the wildfires. Yesterday on our drive to South Lake Tahoe we saw from the car a fire on the mountains and just now, after setting up my tent and starting cooking dinner, I saw that there’s a fire south from where I’m camping. By the amount of smoke it seemed that it had just started but now (8:30pm) it’s worse. The wind is blowing to the other side so I really believe there’s no risk for me. In any case I didn’t put the rain fly on so I can be a bit vigilant during the night.

all_steps.name: Sunrises and Snakebite
all_steps.description:
Day 83
Mile 1174.7 to mile 1203.5
PCT Miles: 28.8 (46.1km)
Total Miles: 1203.5 (1925.6km)

This was my warmest night on the PCT. I’m happy that I swapped my -15°C sleeping bag (1kg) for a 0°C quilt (600g) last week!

As it happens every time that I sleep without the rain fly, I could see the stars during the night and it’s so cool! The sky was very clear and I could see *a lot* of stars!

Gladly when I woke up the fire from yesterday was gone. I met a hiker (Hatchet, I think) early in the morning who told me the fire was 10 miles south from Donner Pass (where I re-started the PCT yesterday). Good that I was already past it 😮‍💨.

Inspired by a beautiful sunrise, I did 12 miles before 10am. I kept pushing until 2:30pm, when I had covered already 22 miles! My thermometer 🌡️ peaked at 39° so I took a good break in the shade after hiking the other seven miles. Even though the mosquitoes were present in the morning they gave me a break in the afternoon!

In one of my breaks, while I was filtering water, an older hiker approached and started to chat. His name was Snakebite, he was 75 and he was from Japan! I had such a good chat with him (some in English some in Japanese), talking about the Shikoku Pilgrimage that I did with Maike last year). I made him cry when I said that I want to be genki like him when I’m 75. Since he hikes in a slower pace, I don’t think I’m going to see Snakebite again. Ganbatte Snakebite-san! Ki o tsukette!

While I write this post (already in my tent, ready to sleep) the sun is setting beautifully. I hope I wake up tomorrow before the sunrise to watch it 🌄👀!

PS: A rattlesnake (!) rattled at me today. I was not expecting to see rattlesnakes anymore! I’m glad that nothing happened… it would be pretty ironic to be bitten by a snake on the day I met Snakebite!

all_steps.name: Am I in the desert again?
all_steps.display_name: Am I in the desert again?
all_steps.description:
Day 84
Mile 1203.5 to mile 1235.9
PCT Miles: 32.4 (51.8km)
Total Miles: 1235.9 (1977.4km)

Since I didn’t use the rain fly on the tent I could feel the wind in the early morning. It was the first time on the PCT that this early breeze was warm.

During the day my thermometer went up to 41°C and I could feel it. Today I drank 12 liters of water and could drink more right now, but I have to save water because tomorrow the day starts with a 16 miles stretch without water and I have only 3 liter with me.

I took 2 longer-than-average one hour breaks, at 10am and at 15am, close to the water and under the shade. I cameled up 2 liters of water on each break.

I’m getting more and more confident that, mile-wise, I will be able to be in Old Station’s post office by Monday morning. The problem is that I’ve been eating a lot and I might need to either start rationing my food on the coming days or stop in a town to do a mini-resupply before grabbing my package 📦 in Old Station.

all_steps.name: Forest of dead trees
all_steps.description:
Day 85
Mile 1235.9 to mile 1268.6
PCT Miles: 32.7 (52.3km)
Total Miles: 1268.6 (2029.8km)

I’m getting really good at packing up in the morning.  It took me 25 minutes today from waking up to be hiking (from 5:20 to 5:45)!

During the day I realized that there was a resort/restaurant about 30 miles from where I started. I decided to try to get there before they closed (which I wrongly believed it was at 9pm). If I could get a meal and maybe some snacks, I would be more comfortable with the amount of food that I have until the next resupply.

I hiked fast in the morning through a forest of dead trees, result of a wildfire a few years ago. Not the best landscape. I did almost 15 miles at 11am.

Once again, it was hot. Sometimes it amazes me how much I sweat and how much water I can drink. Today should be the last day of this heatwave (it’s already much cooler than previous nights now). 

I was looking for a good place to have lunch and suddenly there was this perfect spot by the riverside, with shade and a nice way to enter the river. I went for a swim and spent more than one an a half hour there! It felt great to scrub off the salt 🧂 that’s been accumulating on my skin for the past 4 days!

For the next four hours (10 miles) the path had  4000ft of elevation gain with almost no shade. After liters of sweat, I finally make it to the top, where I had a big shade break at the water source there. I had to filter 6 liters of water, since I drank 4 liters in one go.

This was the moment that I realized that the resort/restaurant’s closing time was 7pm (and not 9). It would be almost impossible to make it in time. I decided not to take the side trail there and keep hiking further. I’ll figure out the food situation in another opportunity.

Along the way there were boxes with books for hikers! I miss reading so much, but I definitely don’t have the time and energy at the moment. Good night 🥱!

(I bought a bag of savory nuts to mix with my granola. I wanted to buy the plain salted nuts but unfortunately I bought by mistake a flavor with herbs (rosemary, oregano and more) and olives. I accidentally created “olivranola” and it’s absolutely disgusting 🤮!)

all_steps.name: Belden Town in-and-out
all_steps.description:
Day 86
Mile 1268.6 to mile 1296.6
PCT Miles: 28.0 (44.8km)
Total Miles: 1296.6 (2074.6km)

Once again, beautiful sunrise! 

My next chance to find a quick resupply was Belden, twenty miles away. It’s located literally on the PCT and it looks tiny. Hopefully I would be able to buy a few snacks to top up my food for the coming 3 days.

I went on auto-pilot and before 1:30pm I was in Belden Town. It’s a street with 5 wooden houses and a big building containing a general store, a simple restaurant (!) and a hotel. Everybody is super hiker friendly and, most importantly, they had air conditioning!

After eating a burger with fries and five beers* I resupplied with snickers and two gigantic packs of cookies. Hopefully I have just the right amount of food now! I also recharged a bit my power bank and posted here on Polarsteps 🙃.

Two and a half hours after arriving I left Belden. It’s the first time (I think) that I do this on the PCT: arrive, resupply/eat and leave (without spending the night). I’m on a mission!

The next 8 miles were under a scorching sun and very uphill. I drank 6 liters of water within the first hour but steady and slowly I made it to camp.

In Belden I saw Sprouts, a Canadian girl who I met at Scout and Frodo and started the PCT on the same day as me. She has just arrived with Banana Bread (a guy from New Zealand who speaks Portuguese) to share the campground. The three
of us chatted a bit and updated each other on the current stage of the members of our first group!

*: all the beers I’ve been drinking on the PCT are non-alcoholic. I’m not drinking alcohol on this trip!

all_steps.name: Midpoint 📍
all_steps.description:
Day 87
Mile 1296.6 to mile 1324.9
PCT Miles: 28.3 (45.3km)
Total Miles: 1324.9 (2119.8km)

The most interesting part of my whole morning was stopping to camel up and fill to all my water capacity (currently 4 liters) for the shadeless and waterless stretch ahead. The spring was very convenient 😊.

Around 12:30 the sun started to get really hot. I was halfway to a water spring (which was 15 minutes off trail) and I had just enough (lukewarm) water to make it to the spring. And then.

Trail magic 🪄!

Free fresh food and cold drinks. Differently from the usual trail magic, there were no cliff bars or m&ms or junk food in general. There were actually a lot of homemade food! Potato salad, fruit salad, home baked cookies, muffins, sandwiches. Fresh fruit and vegetables from one of the trail angel’s garden. All there absolutely for free for thru hikers to satisfy their hunger. It was the best trail magic I’ve experienced so far.

After almost three hours eating cantaloupes and watermelons and cherries and strawberries and apples and bananas and peaches and blueberries and raspberries and grapes and kiwis and pineapples — seriously! all those fruits! — plus cookies, muffins and a sandwich or two, I cameled up for the coming 17 miles without water (and dry camping tonight). The rest of the afternoon was hot, but not as much as the previous days.

Right before my camp site for tonight, I passed the PCT midpoint mark 🎉! It took me almost three months to do the first half. I want to finish the second half in less than two months! Cheers 🥂!

There were a lot more of forests of dead trees today (and I think it will continue for a few days still). I learned that these black dead trees are called widowmakers. I’m actually camping tonight surrounded by them and it’s really creepy and a bit frightening how they indeed creek and squeak. And sometimes you hear branches falling out of the blue. Tonight I’m happy that it’s not windy 😮‍💨.

all_steps.name: Clouds and sock wash
all_steps.description:
Day 88
Mile 1324.9 to 1347.4
PCT Miles: 22.5 (36.0km)
Total Miles: 1347.4 (2199.0km)

Not much has happened in the morning. I’ve been trying to shorten the time between waking up and start hiking. This morning it took me a bit over 20 minutes.

I crossed paths again with Sprouts, Banana Bread and 40 Count — the three of them trying to hitch to town. I’m skipping this town (Chester) and instead I’ll get (hopefully 😬) my package that I sent to myself in the next town, Old Station!

I had a wonderful lunch break by the river. I knew I would have a “short” day today (around 23 miles) so took my time and soaked my feet in the cold water and scrubbed the dirt and all the ash off. My socks were so dirty and full of salt from feet sweat that they were stiff. It was actually hurting a bit as if I was wearing wooden socks. I vigorously washed them (in this heat and sun, they dried up in 20 minutes) and spent two hours chilling and eating my last portion of disgusting olivranola. I can’t wait for my package with more variety of food 🥴.

Soon after my break some clouds started to show up (I don’t think I’ve seen clouds since I restarted the PCT) and it made the afternoon hike much more pleasant. I ended up my hiking day at 4:30 and for the first time in a long time I had time to stretch and enjoy some chill time between dinner and writing polarsteps/going to sleep. Now it’s actually pretty busy here at the camp site. There are at least 9 other hikers camping here tonight ☺️.

all_steps.name: More clouds and swimming
all_steps.description:
Day 89
Mile 1347.4 to mile 1370.8
PCT Miles: 23.4 (37.4km)
Total Miles: 1370.8 (2193.3km)

From waking up to hiking in 20 minutes!

Still a lot of dead trees. It was cloudy for almost the whole day. The path was flat and mega easy to hike.

With the overcast, the breaks to filter water also become quicker since I don’t need to drink so much. I listened to music or podcasts all day long.

I’m camped in this best camping spot since a while already. There’s a creek and there’s a great spot to swim (did already ✅). I arrived at camp at 4pm and had plenty of time to stretch, swim, cook, wash and dry my shirt, filter water and just chill. 

Tomorrow the post office opens at 11am and the General Store at 9am. I’m 4 miles away from Old Station so I should be there by 8am. The plan is to get my box, recharge my devices a bit, hopefully have internet to get more info about the wildfires ahead and move on!

all_steps.name: Old Station in-and-out
all_steps.description:
Day 90
Mile 1370.8 to mile 1385.8
PCT Miles: 15.0 (24.0km)
Total Miles: 1385.8 (2217.3km)

Nothing like a swim in the river and “clean” clothes to make you sleep well. Yesterday I was ready to sleep at 7pm but I forced myself to stay awake until 8. Then I slept like a stone until 5:30.

I arrived in Old Station at 7:30 and found exactly what I was looking for: a power outlet and internet connection! Now I had what to do until the general store opened (at 9). The post office opens at 11.

There was only one cliff bar left of all my food. I was starving (and very happy that my food lasted exactly what it needed to last). I was the first customer at the general store (and at the post office too). For breakfast I had two frozen burritos (microwaved at the store), two ice cream sandwiches, a big cup of coffee and a six pack of beer. I love this day already!

When the post office opened and I asked for
my package, Renée, the awesome clerk who works there, told me that she was wondering whose this package was, because it was so colorful. Artwork from Maike and Jessica 💜!

I was very happy that my box was there. Now, I have food for 8-9 days again! My initial plan was to go to Etna (225 miles away), but the town is under evacuation because of a wildfire. 

After mile 1600 there’s a part of the PCT that is closed (and will mos likely be closed for the entire year since the Shelly fire literally crosses the PCT). I still need to figure out what I’m going to do, but I’ll do that later. At least for the coming five days I’m far away from the fire, so I don’t need to decide now.

In any case, today I sent my inflatable sleeping mattress and my extra clothes to Ashland, Oregon. I haven’t been using them since last week and with this heat I doubt I will. Now I sleep using the sleeping pad only and my only extra clothes are 1 pair of socks and 1 puff jacket!

I liked the idea of mailing myself a resupply
box so much that I’m brewing a plan in my mind to mail myself all the remaining food for the PCT once I’m in Ashland in around 10 days. Let me think more about this and I’ll share here soon!

all_steps.name: Burney Mountain Guest Ranch
all_steps.description:
Day 91
Mile 1385.8 to Burney Mountain Guest Ranch
PCT Miles: 25.0 (40.0km)
Total Miles: 1410.8 (2257.3km)

The word on trail was that 25 miles ahead there’s a new guest ranch where the owners are super hiker friendly and they have a salt water pool 🏊‍♂️  plus homemade style dinner and breakfast. I wanted to check it out, but since I’m not taking a zero, I had to speed up so I could arrive there in time to enjoy all the things.

I started the day at 5:30am and hiked the 25 miles almost non-stop for 9 hours, only pausing to filter water once. By 2:30pm I was at the Burney Mountain Guest Ranch and at 3pm I was eating pizza and having a cold drink! 

After 10 days I’m finally taking a shower and doing laundry! I also had plenty of time to enjoy the salt water pool and order my next resupplies to Ashland (I’ll write a post explaining my next resupply strategy when I’m there) and I’m sleeping on a bunk bed tonight 🛌! There are six other hikers staying here this night. For dinner we had burgers and tons of fresh salad and I already can’t wait for breakfast tomorrow!

all_steps.name: No rest for the wicked
all_steps.description:
Day 92
Burney Mountain Guest Ranch to mile 1435.7
PCT Miles:  24.9 (39.8km)
Total Miles: 1435.7 (2297.1km)

What a lovely place! The Burney Mountain Guest Ranch was my favorite place to stay during the PCT so far!

We had waffles and potatoes and eggs and hash browns for breakfast and after some resistance from my body (who really wanted to stay and take a zero 0️⃣) I left BMGR a bit before 10am.

I then hiked 15 miles in exactly 5 hours (a super good pace!) and took a nice lunch break by a river, under a bridge (shade!). I initially had planned to hike only 15 miles today, but since I was feeling good, I kept hiking for five miles more until I found an awesome camping spot!

all_steps.name: Deers and water management
all_steps.description:
Day 93
Mile 1435.7 to mile 1465.0
PCT Miles:  29.3 (46.9km)
Total Miles: 1465.0 (2344.0km)

From waking up to trail in 20 minutes, I started the day in a good rhythm.

It’s still very hot and I need to always be vigilant with my water: everyday I need to make sure that I know where I’m going to refill my water and figure out how much water I want to carry from one source to the next.

My golden rule so far is 1 liter of water every 4 miles. If the next source is 10 miles away, I pack 2.5 liters of water. Easy.

Because I’m hiking a bit faster now, I’m changing that rule to be 1 liter every 6 miles, specially if it’s not scalding hot. If it’s hot and there’s no shades, I do 1 liter every 3-4 miles.

I don’t know exactly how, but around lunch time, right after refilling my water (2 liters for the next 12.5 miles under the sun) I stopped to take some pictures of Mount Shasta and continued to hike. Half an hour later (about 1.2 miles) I see a hiker that I was sure was behind me coming on the opposite direction. I knew already what had happened:

“I’m going back, aren’t I?” I asked the other hiker. “Yup” was the obvious answer.

I lost a whole hour, hiked 2.4 miles for absolutely nothing and the worst: now I had to hike almost 15 miles with 2 liters of water only and at the warmest time of the day. Great 🙂‍↔️!

In the end everything went well. I’m managed my water very carefully and when I finally arrived at the source, the water was fresh and cold, so it felt like a prize 🏆.

In this part of the PCT there are deers everywhere and they absolutely don’t care about us. I crossed a few on trail today and right now there’s one here at the campsite, acting like he’s the campsite patrol 🏕️🦌👮.

all_steps.name: Planning how to escape the fire
all_steps.display_name: Planning how to escape the fire
all_steps.description:
Day 94
Mile 1465.0 to mile 1497.5
PCT Miles:  32.5 (52km)
Total Miles: 1497.5 (2396.0km)

Today was a good hiking day. Since leaving camp at 5:45 I kept a good pace. The trail was mostly flat and it’s much more enjoyable to hike early in the morning, before the sun shows up with full power.

My first real break was around noon, after having crushed 17 miles already. I took a 45 minute lunch break and then kept going for one and a half hour more. Time for another break (with trail angel candies) and to camel up 🐫🆙 for the next stretch: 10 miles uphill in the hottest time of the day.

At least here the trees 🌲 still have their leaves and they provided good shade. I kept more or less the same pace until I arrived at camp around 7:30pm after hiking 52km today!

all_steps.name: Mount Shasta in-and-out
all_steps.description:
Day 95, part 1
Mile 1497.5 to 1501.7
PCT Miles:  4.2 (6.7km)
Total Miles: 1501.7 (2402.7km)

Before sleeping yesterday, I had internet connection so I could successfully arrange a ride to Mount Shasta at 8am today. This is the first step in order to go around the fire. The next one is to find a more difficult ride: from Mount Shasta to Seiad Valley. 

With that, I’m officially skipping my first PCT miles: 155.3 miles in total. Shelly fire, this is for you 🖕!

I arrived at the trailhead at 7:20am and my ride was already there. Doc told me he does this for a few years now and last year alone he gave rides for more than 1400 hikers!

He also had cookies, bananas and chips. Doritos for pre-breakfast? Why not?

We waited twenty minutes for a group of hikers that Doc was also going to bring to town. Everything was ahead of schedule and by 8am I was already ordering my mushroom breakfast burrito with peanut butter latte in town. I devoured my food while charging my devices!

While charging, I was lucky enough to find another trail angel on the internet, Beth, who was going to pickup a hiker on a trailhead further north and bring to Seiad Valley — exactly where I wanted to be! She agreed to pick me up at 1pm, so I had a few hours to kill in Mount Shasta. I went to a nice coffee shop, updated myself about the wildfires around, uploaded the last Polarsteps posts and had a whole pint of Ben and Jerry’s!

all_steps.name: Seiad Valley in-and-out
all_steps.description:
Day 95, part 2
Mile 1501.7 to mile 1658.2 (skipped 1501.7 to 1657.0)
PCT Miles: 1.2 (1.9km)
Total Miles: 1658.2 (2653.1km)

(I’m skipping 155.3 miles today (Shelly fire 🖕). For simplicity’s sake I’ll add those miles to the total miles.)

The drive to Seiad Valley was longer than I thought and after picking up the hiker (it was 40 Count, a hiker that a met recently!) we drove for almost 3 hours to arrive. It was insanely hot, so I took a break until 6pm inside the general store (which basically IS Seiad Valley) with 40 Count and Speedy (she was there already when we arrived).

At 6pm, still very warm and hazy 🌫️ because of all the smoke coming from Shelly Fire (🖕), the three of us started hiking very slowly (it’s a big uphill climb to leave the valley). After only 1.2 miles both me and Speedy called it a day and 40 Count kept hiking up.

—

About Shelly fire (🖕):

Almost three weeks ago, part of the PCT was closed around mile 1600, because there’s a wildfire burning exactly where the trail is. Most of the alternates to go around the fire by foot are not allowed or are not very smart.

In order to keep my two main rules alive (1. Don’t die; 2. Make wise decisions), I decided to leave the trail before getting too close to the fire. 

The highway to Mount Shasta that I took this morning is 100 miles before the PCT closure, but it’s the more correct place to exit the PCT: if you hike further, you’ll need that someone picks you up in a dirt or service road and run the risk of being on the way of firemen 👨‍🚒 that really need to use those roads.

I struggled a bit in the beginning with the fact that I’m finally breaking my continuous footpath from Mexico to Canada, but it’s a no-brainer that I have to do it. I already accepted the idea and I’m fine with it. I’m now hoping that this is the only fire that I need to dodge from (I don’t think it will be 😞).

If everything goes well and the stars align, there’s also the possibility for me to come back here after (if) I reach Canada and hike this missing part. Time will tell.

all_steps.name: Up, smoke and trickles
all_steps.description:
Day 96
Mile 1658.2 to mile 1686.3
PCT Miles: 28.1 (45.0km)
Total Miles: 1686.3 (2698.1km)

I was not exactly expecting so much elevation gain today, but the trail leaving Seiad Valley is super steep. It was a tough day: it felt like I was hiking uphill all the time. My watch says I climbed the equivalent of 412 stairs today and it was the day that I burned more calories ever (5478 kcal)!

For the whole day I could see the smoke in the horizon. I must say that I enjoyed the view, but it’s kind of scary to realize that something is burning so close and the air quality is far from ideal. The more I hiked (further and up), the better it became to breathe.

Water is getting a little bit tricky to get. I refilled my water three times today, all of them in very trickly streams. Well, at least there is water and I never needed to carry more than 3 liters at once.

The positive side of all the elevation gain is that it’s much cooler now. The past night was so warm that it was difficult for me to sleep. I have a feeling that tonight I’ll sleep very well 🥱.

all_steps.name: Bye California, hi Oregon!
all_steps.description:
Day 97
Mile 1686.3 to mile 1713.5
PCT Miles: 27.2 (43.5km)
Total Miles: 1713.5 (2741.6km)

After 100 days in California, I finally crossed the state line today and I’m now in Oregon!

I was a bit apprehensive because a few days ago there was a fire (Donomore fire) at the border and some people had to take a road alternate. Luckily there was no signs of fire or detour, so I just kept hiking the PCT.

I saw some cows today and I must say that I was very glad that they had cowbells to announce their presence before you could actually see them. I like cows 🐮🫶.

Starting tomorrow I will cold soak my food for the coming two weeks. That means that I’m going to use cold water to prepare (soak) the food instead of cooking it. For ramen, for example, you put the noodles and cold water in a jar 🫙, close it and leave for 1-2 hours and voilá! You have dinner!

Because of that, tomorrow I’m also going to send my stove by post to the last town in Oregon (or the first in Washington — I’m not sure yet). Tonight I cooked my last dinner and I was wondering what I would do with my gas canister, which was almost full and you can’t mail a gas canister. 

Right after I ate, I heard some gas leaking on the campsite next to me and a man that I had never seen before, Compass, told me that his gas canister broke and he had just started going southbound to Seiyad Valley (exactly the opposite of what I did in the past days). He asked if I didn’t have an extra gas canister by any chance… what are the odds?

all_steps.name: Nearo into Ashland
all_steps.description:
Day 98, part 1
Mile 1713.5 to Ashland
PCT Miles: 6.2 (9.9km)
Total Miles: 1719.7 (2751.5km)

It’s town day! Going downhill, backpack as light as it can be, beautiful morning and feeling rested after sleeping for almost ten hours!

I had internet yesterday at camp, so I could arrange a ride with the hotel I’ll stay at tonight: it’s a new hotel and word on trail is that it’s a cool one and most importantly, hiker friendly.

I arrived at the trailhead at 8am and waited for one hour until Jay showed up on this gigantic car. Air conditioning blasting, I almost froze during our 25 minutes ride to Ashland. On the way, Jay, who owns the hotel, told me more about it.

She recently bought and renovated this hotel, moved to Ashland last December and opened it in April this year: it’s her first hiking season! Since my room was already free, she let me check in at 10am and I could finally, after one week, shower. My body was completely covered in dust, salt and ash.

I loved this place! The Columbia Hotel! It’s fully decorated with local artists paintings 🖼️ that are all on sale. They have local DJs playing every now and then and the rooms and common spaces look beautiful. It’s almost calling me to take a zero…

all_steps.name: Packing and delivering 📦
all_steps.description:
Day 98, part 2

After taking a shower, time to collect all my packages. I had a few at the hotel and a few more to collect at the post office 🏤. I got all these packages because I have an ambitious plan for all the remaining resupplies!

On day 90, at the post office in Old Station, I met Diesel and Red Lentils and I was amused by their resupply strategy: they had a gigantic box with basically all the food they will need for the whole PCT. They send this box to themselves from time to time and when they receive it (like now), they prepare the 2-3 next resupply boxes and send this big box further away and when they reach there, they repeat the process. By doing that, they “do groceries” much quicker and easier and still give them a lot of flexibility.

So that’s what I’m doing here today! I bought 30+ dinner packs, 200+ energy bars and absurd amounts of electrolytes, wet wipes and other amenities and made myself three boxes: two resupply boxes for Oregon and one box with everything else that I sent to the last town in Oregon, 400+ miles away: Cascade Locks. “Everything else” includes my mattress, fleece, puff jacket, extra sock, old shoes (that might be useful still) and, notably, my stove and cooking pot!

In order to reduce time spent with anything other than hiking and to make things simpler, I’ll hike through Oregon stoveless. That means I will cold soak 🫙 my food instead of cooking them. Other than (cold) dinner, all my other meals will be composed by bars or other foods that I can eat while walking! I sent ahead my warm clothes, sleeping mattress and now my warm food… I feel that I’m little by little removing all the pleasures from my life 😂!

Before closing the boxes, I went to the supermarket to buy more bars and nuts to put in them. The post office closed at 5pm and I was there at 4:50pm! Mission accomplished ✅!

all_steps.name: Oregon starts
all_steps.description:
Day 99
Ashland to mile 1742.3
PCT Miles: 22.6 (36.2km)
Total Miles: 1742.3 (2787.7km)

I really enjoyed staying at The Columbia Hotel! So far, my favorite place to stay on the PCT! Jay, I wish all the success to your business! Thank you for picking me up and dropping me off at the trailhead!

In the morning I went to two different coffee shops before Jay would drop me off at 9am. I had a nice avocado toast for breakfast and I was ready to start the next section of the PCT!

Hiking was chill without surprises. It’s much less warm than the previous days and the path was very mild elevation-wise. Even though I started hiking after 9:30am, by 6pm I was already at the campsite, 22.6 miles ahead! Good out-of-town day!

My backpack has never been so light when leaving  town after resupplying. I’m bringing food for only 4 days and I hope to grab my package with more food on the fifth day. Tonight was also my first time cold soaking and I must say that I enjoyed my dinner very much (which is good, because I have the same dinner for the coming 12 nights!).

My plan is to hike Oregon as fast as I can. I want to finish hiking in Oregon in less than two weeks and finally take a zero in Cascade Locks (where I sent all my stuff to), just across the river from Washington (the last state of the PCT).

all_steps.name: Day 💯 with Trail Magic
all_steps.description:
Day 100
Mile 1742.3 to mile 1777.3
PCT Miles: 35.0 (56.0km)
Total Miles: 1777.3 (2843.7km)

I started hiking a little bit later than I wanted today: the morning was chilly and my thermometer was showing 5 degrees celsius. I wasn’t expecting any of my nights here in Oregon to be that cold. Gladly my sleeping quilt (and not bag) did a good job 👍.

I’m trying to take advantage of the fact that Oregon is relatively flat to crush miles. Water is still more scarce than I imagined, but this actually helps since I stop less often to filter water (but I have longer and heavier water carries). 

By 2pm I had already hiked 20 miles in a very uneventful morning. I was carrying 3 liters of water for the next 18 miles when I crossed paths with two southbounders smiling at me: “you have trail magic ahead!”. These are the words that every thru hiker loves to hear.

Ten minutes later there was it: trail angels had set a big tent with food and chairs. There were hammocks and games to play. They were making burgers 🍔! I had two. And chips. And cookies. And cinnamon roll. And blueberry muffin 🫐🧁 . And cantaloupes🍈 . And watermelon 🍉. And cherries 🍒. And strawberries 🍓. 

All of that in 40 minutes: I kept an eye on my watch. I didn’t want to be vortexed and miss my goal of 35 miles for today. I thanked the trail angels but it was time to go (with a very full belly).

An uneventful afternoon followed. The weather today was much better than the past days, so it was pleasant to hike, without sweating too much and having to drink (and carry) lots of water.

I arrived at camp at ten past eight. I made my cold soaked dinner, pitched my tent and observed the deers around the campsite. As I’m writing this (it’s 9:30pm) I can hear the deers walking around and getting closer to my tent. I know they like to lick the salt on hikers teaming poles handles. Well, I hope I can ignore them and sleep well 🙃!

all_steps.name: Planning around Trail Fire
all_steps.description:
Day 101
Mile 1777.3 to mile 1811.9
PCT Miles: 34.6 (55.4km)
Total Miles: 1811.9 (2899.0km)

Except for the hiker i overtake that was reading a book _while_ hiking, absolutely nothing out of the ordinary happened today. So I’ll write about the next trail closure (which is 12 miles ahead of me) and my plan for tomorrow.

When I left Ashland, I knew that the Trail Fire plus some other fires around Diamond Peak Wilderness forced the PCT to be closed from mile 1848.8 to 1907.2. But yesterday I heard that the closure starts now at mile 1824.0.

I don’t have internet to check any of that, but on my map it seems that I can circumvent this closure by doing the alternate on the Crater Rim Trail (which I would do anyway). I believe the vast majority of PCTers do the rim trail alternate.

Tomorrow I’ll go fast in the morning to arrive at Crater Lake’s cafe (15 miles away) before noon and get more information about the closures. I only have one more day of food, so I need to find a way to get to the end of the closure (mile 1907.2) where my resupply package hopefully awaits for me.

all_steps.name: Crater Lake Rim Trail
all_steps.description:
Day 102
Mile 1811.9 to mile 1840.3
PCT Miles: 28.4 (45.4km)
Total Miles: 1840.3 (2944.5km)

Around midnight a deer 🦌 started to wander around my tent. They’re known to come at night to lick 👅 or chew on your trekking poles handles or backpack straps). I tried to send them away a few times but at some point I just gave up and sent back to sleep. My stuff seemed untouched in the morning.

When I finally woke up I was a bit in bad mood. My Garmin was acting a bit weird and I was anxious about the fire ahead: the only info I had was from this random girl at the trail magic two days ago who told me that the PCT would be closed earlier than we were expecting: at mile 1824, at the junction with the Crater Lake Rim Trail.

Instructions were unclear, so I hiked fast in the morning. On the way I met Bilbo, English 26-years old dude. I had never seen him before. We hiked together for about one hour and we chatted during that time. Or, better said, Bilbo chatted with me. He told me about his life back in England, his time in the army, how he wanted to be deployed in Iraq during covid, his misfortunes with women and jobs and his aspirations to become a paramedic. He told me a lot.

He exited the trail earlier, afraid that the trail would be closed ahead and we would have to turn around and go back.

The trail was indeed closed at mile 1824.0 but I the alternative was to take the Crater Lake Rim Trail, which I did, arriving at the restaurant at Crater Lake Park parking lot at 11am. I was so looking forward for having breakfast AND lunch there. Unfortunately the kitchen was closed and I got fries with cheese and pre-packed salad 😐. I had free refills of tea and coffee though.

I stayed there for three hours charging my devices, drinking 3 liters of tea and almost 2 of coffee, using the amazing miracle that are flush toilets 🚽. Most importantly, I was trying to figure out a plan to go around the fire and arrive at Shelter Cove (80 miles ahead) tomorrow. My resupply package is there and I currently have less than one day of food.

The Rim Trail was actually very beautiful and enjoyable to hike for the first few miles. After that though the smoke started to thicken and I could feel the smoke on my sore eyes and throat. Not much I could do at this point, I kept hiking.

In the meanwhile I got a message from Free Mile, a hiker that I’ve been leapfrogging with and to whom I talked to at the Crater Lake “Restaurant”. He said he had secured a ride for us tomorrow at noon from highway 138 (8 miles from where I’m camping tonight) to Shelter Cove. Awesome!

The trail from tonight’s campsite to highway 138 is actually closed, as part of the same closure from earlier today. To get there, we will do a 8 miles road walk, parallel to the PCT.

Arrived early at camp and the air quality here seems ok. On my way here I rationed my snacks and I only ate half of my dinner tonight, just in case. For tomorrow, until I get to Shelter Cove, I have half a dinner and three snack bars (which should be more than enough).

all_steps.name: Road walk
all_steps.description:
Day 103, part 1
Mile 1840.3 to mile 1848.8
PCT Miles: 8.5 (13.6km)
Total Miles: 1848.8 (2958.1km)

This past night I had one of the coldest night experiences here on the PCT. Not only because it went below freezing, but mainly because I’m not bringing warmer clothes for this part of the trail. Well, it happens.

I had agreed with Free Mile to meet at highway 138 at noon. He would leave earlier to go back a few miles and have breakfast with Soybean, his wife, with a view to the Crater Lake. I started hiking a bit after 6 and soon reached the road, where I would hike for the next 8 miles.

To be honest it was not that bad. It took a while for the sun to warm me up but the views were beautiful and it was too early for the roads to be busy with cars. After eating all my remaining snack bars along the way, I arrived at the meeting point at 9:30am. 

For breakfast, I just had the half that I saved from my dinner yesterday at the best hikertrash style, by the roadside. Now I’m 100% without food, so I hope Free Mile (and specially our ride) really show up 😬!

all_steps.name: Smoke
all_steps.description:
Day 103, part 2
Mile 1907.6 to mile 1912.5 (skipped from mile 1848.8 to mile 1907.6 (58.8 miles) due official PCT wildfire-related closures: Middle Fork Fire, Trail Fire and Diamond Peak Fire)
PCT Miles: 4.9 (7.8km)
Total Miles: 1912.5 (3060.0km)

Gladly at 11am Free Mile showed up with Soybean and Lucky and even better our ride also showed up! During the car ride I was very sleepy and barely remember a thing. It took us around 1 and a half hour to arrive at Shelter Cove Resort. There was smoke everywhere.

I got my resupply box that I sent to myself back in Ashland (day 98), ate a burger with double fries, drank liters of water and charged my devices. Besides having a snack bar with burgers, pizzas and burritos, Shelter Cove also offers free camping for PCT hikers. The temptation to take the rest of the day off was building up.

But I wanted to keep hiking. Today marks the start of my fourth week without taking a single zero! I bought myself a pint of Ben & Jerry and decided that I was going to leave as soon as I finished it. At 4:20pm I was on the road hiking 1.5 mile back to rejoin the PCT!

From the moment I left the car in Shelter Cove until now (8pm), I can not only smell the smoke but also feel it in my eyes and throat. I don’t think I’ve ever been exposed to such amount of smoke for so much time. I hope tomorrow I can hike away from this unpleasant smoke.

The five miles hike from Shelter Cove to tonight’s campsite was very chill. There was the smoke, of course, but at least it was not hot and the views were beautiful. I’m camping tonight between two lakes in one of the most beautiful campsites I had so far. I hope it doesn’t get *too* cold during the night 🥶.

all_steps.name: The trail provides
all_steps.description:
Day 104
Mile 1912.5 to mile 1948.2
PCT Miles: 35.7 (57.1km)
Total Miles: 1948.2 (3117.1km)

Smoke-wise the day started much better than it ended yesterday. If you were persistent, you could even spot a blue sky!

An old friend (or horde of friends) that have slowly showing up are the mosquitoes. To be honest I expected it to be worse (knock knock knock ✊🪵), but even a few mosquitoes are enough to ruin a day.  In the morning I hiked mostly covered with my rain gear and mosquito net. Gladly it hasn’t been warm in the past days.

Around lunchtime I crossed paths with a southbounder and he told me that I had a fun surprise ahead. Usually that means one thing: trail magic!

And indeed, instead of energy bars, I had hot dogs, chips and iced tea for lunch! The trail angels, Ducky’s Mom and Ducky’s Dad, started trail angeling when their son (Ducky, of course) finished his PCT and urged them to become trail angels (they live relatively close to the PCT). Ducky’s Mom and Ducky’s Dad have been doing this now every year since 2016!

Once again I couldn’t stay as much as I wanted and needed to keep going after 40 minutes. Even though I had hiked already 13 miles (21km) in the morning I still had another 23 miles (37km) to hike!

The afternoon was very uneventful, but mostly not pleasant. Smoke, mosquitoes and burned areas took turns into making me company. I kept a good pace and since it wasn’t hot today I didn’t need to filter and drink so much water.

I’m having intense weeks with a lot of 30+ miles days and although my legs feel great, my feet are starting to hurt a little. I hope everything stays in place for a bit more, since my next planned zero is in about eight days.

all_steps.name: Happily mosquitoless
all_steps.description:
Day 105
Mile 1948.2 to mile 1980.2
PCT Miles: 32.0 (51.2km)
Total Miles: 1980.2 (3168.3km)

For the past two nights I’ve been setting my tent up with the rain fly, so it serves as a barrier against the chilly wind. Therefore I was accidentally prepared for the rain that fell this past night.

In the morning the rain had stopped but I left camp wearing my rain pants and jacket, not against the rain but against the mosquitoes. To be fair there were very few in the morning, but I was sure it was going to get worse during the day. It didn’t.

Hiking was chill, with good weather and improving smoke situation. The water sources today were much better than the past days and surprisingly still very few mosquitoes!

Tomorrow I will get my second and last package here in Oregon. I’m not sure what to do: I’m getting really sick of my Oregon cold food. I can’t wait to have my stove back!

all_steps.name: Big Lake Youth Camp
all_steps.description:
Day 106
Mile 1980.2 to mile 1998.8
PCT Miles: 18.6 (29.8km)
Total Miles: 1998.8 (3198.1km)

Once more I put the rain fly over the tent “just because” and I was glad I did: in the morning all my stuff were full of condensation (sleeping quilt and backpack were the worse) and I was a bit cold. Breaking out camp is always less pleasant when everything you touch is cold and wet.

I had a resupply box waiting for me in 17 miles, at the Big Lake Youth Camp. I also had heard that they’re super hiker friendly, offering a free space for us to rest, shower, do laundry and even get meals! All donation-based.

I arrived at BLYC 1pm which was exactly lunch time! I had my fair share of cheese tostis with tomato soup 🥪🥫and after that I took care of my chores, including drying up my tent and sleeping quilt, still wet from last night. During my afternoon at BLYC, amongst new and familiar faces I saw Rocky (from days 54 and 72), DIY, Free Mile and Soybean. I also met a few other hikers that I hadn’t seen before.

I don’t know exactly how but all of a sudden it was 6:20pm already and that means dinner time! Tortilla chips which beans, cheese, lettuce and tomato 🌮🫘🧀🥬🍅. Delicious!

But the day wasn’t over yet: I didn’t want to stay. I wanted to avoid the risk of being vortexed (tomorrow they serve breakfast at 8:20am, which is too late but I’m sure I’ll wait for it if I stay here tonight). I gathered my last bits of energy and hiked two miles north and found a camping spot.

Fully loaded with snacks and supplies, my next big stop (if everything goes according to the plan, of course), is a all-you-can-eat lunch buffet at Timberline Lodge (google it!), 103 miles ahead. I’ll try to crush 30 miles a day for the next three days and arrive at Timberline Lodge in time for a one in a lifetime Sunday lunch!

all_steps.name: Lakes galore and ugliest camp site ever
all_steps.display_name: Lakes galore and ugliest camp site ever
all_steps.description:
Day 107
Mile 1998.8 to mile 2031.9
PCT Miles: 33.1 (53.0km)
Total Miles: 2031.9 (3251.0km)

I still can’t believe on the low amount of mosquitoes that I’ve faced here in Oregon so far. I still have a few days around here so they might be preparing a sneak attack. But let’s keep our hopes high that they just won’t show up!

The hiking in the morning was very pleasant, with views of at least five beautiful lakes. I can’t say the same about the afternoon, where the astonishing landscape was replaced by miles and miles of burnt trees.

Not much else to share. I crossed paths with a few southbounders today, some thru hikers, some day hikers. Weather went up again so even though I’m staying in a horrible camp site tonight, I hope I can sleep better than the past chilly nights.

all_steps.name: Food alternatives
all_steps.description:
Day 108
Mile 2031.9 to mile 2061.0
PCT Miles: 29.1 (46.7km)
Total Miles: 2061.0 (3297.7km)

I spent almost the whole day today hiking on burnt forests. Not fun, specially when the sun and high temperatures are back.

I had to do something regarding my food. My day food is not the best, but it’s ok (mainly bars and nuts). On the other hand, I’m not enjoying my cold dinners at all. I took a tiny detour today to stop by a resort that had a small shop to see how I could improve my food situation.

Tortillas and nutella, that was the solution that I could come up with given the limited options that I had. I’ve just had dinner now: the same cold soaked cucumbers, tomato, cabbage and seeds salad but this time wrapped in a tortilla with some almonds. I must say that it tasted much better than the salad alone. And for desert I had tortilla with nutella, which has absolutely no problem being served cold.

Tomorrow is Saturday (a good day for trail magic) and I heard that it’s common to have trail magic in this area. I’m hopping I can find an option to skip one more day of eating cold soaked food (in
other words: that I find trail magic). And the day after tomorrow… buffet lunch at Timberline Lodge 🤩!

all_steps.name: Well-timed trail magic!
all_steps.description:
Day 109
Mile 2061.0 to mile 2089.3
PCT Miles: 28.3 (45.3km)
Total Miles: 2089.3 (3342.9km)

It was a very pleasant night with good temperatures and no condensation in the morning.

Right after I left camp I heard something moving on the bushes to my right. Clearly the bear had seen me first and it was already running to the opposite direction. I could only have a glance of its black furred butt and that was it!

After 16 miles, at lunch time — I was ready to eat my 700-calories-lunch-energy-bar-that-I’m-very-fed-up-with — my prayers were heard: there was a trail magic ahead!

I forgot to ask the name of today’s trail angel, but this is what she does: for the past 4 years, every year, she goes camping for about two weeks with her horses on a horse camp (yes, this exists) which is on a very short side trail from the PCT. She brings food for herself, hay for the horses and tons of foods and drinks for the PCT hikers!

I had cheese sandwiches, cookies and chips. It was good to eat something savory other than almonds or my cold-soaked dinners. I ate enough so I could skip dinner tonight (I can’t with my food anymore 😭). 

Having to hike still 13 miles to the camp site, at some point I had to stop eating and continue hiking. Another uneventful afternoon followed and I made camp early, around 6:30pm. For dinner I had wrap with nutella, freeze-dried strawberries and almonds. It was delicious!

Tomorrow we feast!

all_steps.name: Timberline Lodge
all_steps.description:
Day 110
Mile 2089.3 to mile 2105.2
PCT Miles: 15.9 (25.4km)
Total Miles: 2105.2 (3368.3km)

There was nothing else on my mind today other than “buffet lunch at Timberline Lodge”!

Lunch starts being served at 12 and I had easy 10 miles to do in the morning. It was a fairly steep uphill but I was fueled by the excitement to have unlimited fresh and warm food. I arrived at the lodge at 10:30 and had more than enough time to chill and charge my electronics.

The trail was packed with day hikers and tourists. To be honest, it seemed a very nice place to spend a Sunday or a weekend. There were so many families and people of all ages hiking, mountain biking, taking photographs and observing nature with binoculars. I’m not sure all of them understood why some of the hikers (like me) looked so dirty and worn out 🙃.

At 12 on the dot me with a group of other 6 hikers (only one, Andrew, that I already knew) sat on a table and started our little gluttony party. Again, I’m sure our collective smelliness caught some undesired attention from non-thru hikers at the restaurant. On our table, there were piles of meat on the plates of the meat eaters. I had six plates two beers and two beers in front of me. Finally I feel moderately full!

I was expecting a bit more of variety but honestly I can’t complain. I had lots of fresh salad and vegetables, which is luxury on the PCT. I ended up spending five and a half hours at the lodge, charging, resting, calling Maike 💜 and I also left almost all my food on the hiker box. I have now with me only the minimum for dinner tonight (tortilla with nutella) and food for tomorrow. I want to arrive in Cascade Locks (44.2 miles ahead of me) for breakfast on Tuesday🤞!

I hiked just for two more hours and found a cute little spot to camp amongst wildflowers 🌺.

all_steps.name: It’s a gift, dude. It’s a gift.
all_steps.display_name: It’s a gift, dude. It’s a gift.
all_steps.description:
Day 111
Mile 2105.2 to mile 2137.8
PCT Miles: 32.6 (52.2km)
Total Miles: 2137.8 (3420.5km)

It rained the whole night. I was more than happy to have set up my tent’s rain fly again. All my gear (and myself) dry in the morning!

Another day on trail, another day of trail magic! This time it was just this guy who hiked the PCT a while ago and now he’s retired and does trail magic in different parts of the PCT every year. He said his favorite part is when there’s a heatwave and he brings ice cream to the hikers. They go crazy, he said.

Lots of fresh fruits and vegetables later, I continued my day. The plan was to get as close as I could from Cascade Locks, where I have my resupply package waiting for me. Hopefully I will be able to sort all my food for Washington and send 4-5 packages tomorrow still. If that works, I won’t take a zero in Cascade Locks!

The highlight of the day and certainly one of the highlights of the whole trail was Tunnel Falls, on an alternate route that I had to take due a fire closure. This alternate (Eagle Creek Trail) is widely more used than the official PCT path for this section, because the Eagle Creek Trail is so scenic and you can see the Tunnel Falls, this majestic waterfall where you hike behind the falling water through a cold and dark tunnel. It’s absolutely splendid.

Earlier, still in the morning, I crossed paths with a girl who stopped me to ask if I was a PCT thru hiker. I said yes and then she told me that it’s her dream: that one day she would also thru hike the PCT. She looked me in the eye and said “Thru hiking the PCT? it’s a gift, dude. It’s a gift”.

Day 112
Mile 2137.8 to Cascade Locks
PCT Miles: 11.5 (18.4km)
Total Miles: 2149.3 (3438.9km)

The morning was a breeze: 10 miles of pure downhill into Cascade Locks! I was able to arrive before the post office opened at 8:30am!

I successfully got my packages containing 75% of all the food I’ll need for the Washigton section. Two items that I was very looking forward were also in the boxes: flip flops and my stove!! Cold soaking never again!

My plan is to spend the day today sorting everything into small boxes and send four resupply packages ahead. All of that before the post office closes again, at 5am.

On top of that, I needed to take a 30 minutes bus to another town (Hood River) to buy socks and fleece pants (I’m a bit afraid of getting too cold during the nights in Washington). To be able to plan things properly, I needed mind fuel. I stopped for a healthy breakfast before executing my plan: grilled cheese, fries and peanut butter milkshake.

After eating, I needed a room to do all the resupply sorting so I went to the cheapest inn in town. I was able to get an affordable room and check in at 9:30am! Great! Now, the plan was to go to Hood River, buy the equipment and the rest of the food, pack at least the first two resupply boxes and send them today. And leave the other two packages to send tomorrow. The clock was ticking!

My search for socks and fleece pants was successful and so was the groceries run. At 4:30 I  was back at the post office in Cascade Locks just in time to send my boxes to the next two resupply towns: Trout Lake and White Pass! Check ✅!

On the way back to the hotel from the post office I meet some not-so-happy-looking hikers. They quickly shared the news: in the past hour a new fire started, closing the trail from Trout Lake to White Pass. That’s right: this new trail closure starts and ends literally where I had sent my packages to, just a few minutes ago.

The news completely destroyed my mood. I went to a brewery to have a burger (and my third portion of fries of the day) and a local non-alcoholic beer. After that I went back to the hotel and organized the last two boxes and don’t even want to think about another re-route. For now, I’ll just assume that the plan stays the same and that I’ll be leaving tomorrow morning. Let’s see!

all_steps.name: Frustration
all_steps.description:
Day 113
PCT Miles: 0 
Total Miles: 2149.3 (3438.9km)

I had breakfast at a nice artsy coffee shop nearby, where I met some hikers who were on the exact same situation as me: they had arrived two days ago and now they didn’t know what to do.

Me and another hiker even went to the post office as soon as it opened to try to retrieve our boxes back to no avail: the packages were already on their way.

After breakfast I went back to the post office and sent the last two boxes (what could I do?). I had to decide what to do now. Physically, I was ready to start hiking. But I knew I couldn’t start hiking without knowing more about the conditions ahead. Remember: 1) Don’t die; and 2) Make wise decisions.

I decided to take a zero. I booked the inn room for one more night and tried to slow down a little and analyze my options. I was (and am) feeling absolutely frustrated with these fire closures. Now, I have packages all over the place with food that I won’t need and I have to find a way to retrieve them. Also, what am I going to do? Should I wait more? Should I take a bus to Portland and enjoy a few days off? Should I just skip the next 150 miles (I need to find a ride)?

I spent the afternoon listening to music, podcasts, audio books, drinking beer (non-alcoholic) and doing absolutely nothing else. I know Clara (who started the PCT with me) is arriving here in Cascade Locks tomorrow. I’ll wait and discuss the situation with her and her group. 

Now, time to watch some Olympics…

all_steps.name: Unexpectedly back on trail
all_steps.description:
Day 114
Mile 2255.7 to mile 2256.4 (skipped from mile 2149.8 to mile 2255.7 (105.9 miles) due the official PCT William’s Mine Fire closure)
PCT Miles: 0.7 (1.1km)
Total Miles: 2256.4 (3610.2km)

Once more I had a hard time trying to fall asleep. Without any need of waking up early the next morning, I kept watching Olympic Games on the hotel’s TV until way past hiker’s midnight.

I woke up and went to the same coffee shop that I went yesterday and had a breakfast burrito (I’ll miss those!) and an iced latte. I was finishing my coffee when Clara showed up! I wasn’t expecting her to arrive so early. It was so cool to see her and to be able to have a coffee together! Besides day 1, it’s the third time that I meet Clara on trail! 🫶

We, of course, discussed about the ultra recent William’s Mine Fire closure. Apparently the best thing to do would be to skip around 150 miles and go straight to White Pass. Clara told me that she would stay at least one night in Cascade Locks and she would research alternative routes around the fire. She had no idea exactly how to do it, but she wanted to spend some time and energy (and maybe finding some help) to figure out an alternative. Fair enough.

I told her that I was not very enthusiastic about the idea of finding alternative unofficial routes around a wildfire and I would, then, find my way to White Pass. I was in no rush, though. 

Most northbound hikers (like me) are taking the $10 bus to Portland, spending one night there and then finding a ride to White Pass. I decided that I would do the same, but I would spend more time in Portland.

Ok, so here is my plan — I told Clara — I’ll go to Portland, buy a book and spend the weekend chilling and reading. And then next week I find a ride to White Pass and continue the hike. That’s a good plan, she confirmed.

So we left the coffee shop to go meet her group at a restaurant 2 minutes away. As we cross the street somebody shouts: are you northbound hikers? Do you want a ride to White Pass?

In five seconds I changed my plans: yes! I replied. I couldn’t refuse such an easy and unusual ride offer like this. To drive to White Pass you really need to go around the mountains (it’s a 4 hours drive!). I told them (it was a guy and his mom) that I needed to still pack my stuff and check out from my room. No problem, they said. “We still have space for 3 more hikers, you’re the first one”. Great!

Clara shared her plans with them and they replied: “oh, yesterday we spend four hours working on this alternative route and we actually submitted a proposal to the PCTA to accept this route, since we believe it’s pretty safe. Here’s a printed map and a link to the file so you can download the route on your phone!”.

She couldn’t believe what she was listening! This is exactly what she wanted! We said our goodbyes and I rushed to pack and leave. The two trail angels spent almost one hour trying to find other hikers for the ride, but in the end they only found one more. Around noon we left Cascade Locks heading to White Pass!

On the way they explained that they, mother and son, live in Portland and are PCTA volunteers for that section of the PCT. They hiked the PCT together last year and this year they intended to do trail magic exactly at the part of the trail that was closed due this new fire, two days ago. They figured that the best way to help hikers then would be to use the day to give a ride north to White Pass to northbound hikers and on the way back give a ride to Cascade Locks to southbounders. It’s a 4 hours drive each way.

After three hours driving they offered to bring us not to White Pass, but a dozen miles south, closer to where the actual trail closure is. To get there, it would add more than one hour to the trip, driving on forest unpaved and unmaintained roads. That would be amazing, we replied. So that was the new plan!

Right after we agreed on the new route, we saw two hikers hitching right ahead of us. The mom and son (I didn’t ask their names!!) were over the moon to be able to help more hikers. They were clearly a bit unsatisfied driving with only two hikers. Now we were a full car!

When we stopped on the road side and the hikers started loading their backpacks into the car when one of them suddenly asked “Bruno? Is that you?”.

It was Pete (from days 1 and 71)! He and Nick (another guy who I saw a few times already) were actually on trail when it was closed and had to go back and had spent the whole day taking buses after buses to get to White Pass. They were very happy to get the ride and even happier that we were actually driving south of White Pass, meaning less skipped miles.

After a couple of hours we arrived at the junction with the PCT. The four of us hiked for 15 minutes and decided to call it a day. There was a nice large campsite with water nearby and we were mentally exhausted from this day. It was a good call.

And finally, finally, finally I had warm dinner again!

all_steps.name: Goat Rocks and baby bear
all_steps.description:
Day 115
Mile 2256.4 to mile 2287.4
PCT Miles: 31.0 (49.6km)
Total Miles: 2287.4 (3659.8km)

We’re back to magnificent mountain views!

I left camp a bit before 6am, before the other people. I really enjoy — and have been enjoying — to hike alone.

The morning was tough with mosquitoes but before noon the situation had improved. It’s really tough to hike uphill on a warm day wearing your rain clothes against the mosquitoes.

Now I understand why the trail angels yesterday insisted on driving us one more hour so we could hike through the Goat Rocks. The views were absolutely amazing and I could also hike through one of the best named parts of the PCT. It’s this narrow path on a ridge where you have (beautiful) cliffs on both sides. It’s called the Knife’s Edge 🔪.

The main characteristic of the PCT in Washignton are the steep ascends and descents. I totally felt that today. I went up and down on two passes today and that was an extreme exercise for my thighs and knees. At least there’s no significant amount of snow (and I don’t think there will be any for the rest of the trail).

When I was literally seconds away from my campsite I heard something moving in the woods a bit ahead of me. I was sure it was a hiker that was camping at the same spot. Then it started to cross the trail three meters in front of me, completely unaware of my presence. It was a bear. A young, small beautiful brown-colored bear.

I was absolutely in shock. That’s what you always hear about black bears: they’re only a threat if you stand between a mom and her cubs. The bear in front of me was definitely not a grown-up. Besides, differently from California, in Washington they also have grizzly bears, known to be much more aggressive towards humans than black bears (which, despite what the name might suggest, can be black or brown colored).

For a moment I forgot that there was a bear right in front of me and looked around to see if I could spot another bear, the mom. At this moment the young bear noticed me and in a split second ran uphill, away from me and from the campsite. The poor bear ran so fast that you could hear and feel the ground trembling when he stomped away.

I waited a few seconds to see if there would be a follow up event, but I couldn’t hear or see anything atypical. I walked 10 more steps and I was at the campsite. There was one other tent there. When the girl saw me from inside her tent she asked me: “did you hear that? I think it might have been a deer running away”. “Yeah” — I replied — “I think so too”.

all_steps.name: White Pass Kracker Barrel in-and-out
all_steps.description:
Day 116
Mile 2287.4 to mile 2310.0
PCT Miles: 22.6 (36.2km)
Total Miles: 2310.0 (3696.0km)

The first ten miles of the day, from the campsite to White Pass Kracker Barrel (the General Store where my next resupply box is), were under quite some smoke. It was a bit not ideal to breathe but I kept hiking — what else can you do? — and at 10:30 I arrived at Kracker Barrel with no major incidents.

Still in the morning I met the first Brazilians on trail (other than me, of course). It was a couple, Paula and Ramon, and that was the second time that they’re section hiking the PCT (the first time was 2019). 

At Kracker Barrel, the usual in-and-out business: grab the resupply box, charge everything, eat “town food” (frozen burrito and coffee), rest and go back to trail! At 1pm I was already hiking north again.

After resupplying, I’m currently carrying 4 days worth of food. I just realized that this is the last time on the PCT that I will carry such a big amount (it’s crazy to think that I already carried NINE days of food in the Sierra!).

Hiking in the afternoon was pretty chill, with no stress of making big miles. With the last trail closures, I’m at least one week ahead of schedule.
