In fact, because of the upcoming wildfire-related trail closures ahead (where I’ll probably have to skip around 150 miles more), I might be as close as two weeks of finishing the PCT!

all_steps.name: Beautiful Washington
all_steps.description:
Day 117
Mile 2310.0 to mile 2336.9
PCT Miles: 26.9 (43.0km)
Total Miles: 2336.9 (3739.0km)

Completely different from Oregon, the Washington section of the PCT is full of up and downhills. I have the feeling that here the hills are steeper than in most of the PCT.

It’s cool to be in the mountains again and go over passes. In the Sierra, all the passes I crossed were over snow and ice. Here I expect to see almost no snow. It is nice to be able to cross the passes following an actual trail!

There were an impressive amount of day hikers, families, groups of young people today. Since yesterday, the camping spots have been disputed. I said this a few times already, but I think it’s so cool that people hike and camp as a hobby ✨!

Washington so far has been very tough but very beautiful. It’s a good trade off 🙃.

all_steps.name: Mist and cold 🌫️
all_steps.description:
Day 118
Mile 2336.9 to mile 2366.8
PCT Miles: 29.9 (47.9km)
Total Miles: 2366.8 (3786.9km)

I’m glad that I brought warmer clothes for Washington. It was a chilly night and morning.

For most of the day I hiked through a very dense fog/mist. When hiking in the forest, this mist made everything wet and created a kind of rain, creating water drops that would fall from the tree leaves. When hiking on more exposed areas like ridges, I could see the thick mist moving, like a big cloud. 

Besides that, not much to add: it was a nice and calm hiking day. I met some enthusiastic local hikers that congratulated me for being “almost there”, enjoyed a few sun breaks and finished the audiobook “Greenlights” for the second time!

all_steps.name: Huckleberry Fields Forever
all_steps.description:
Day 119
Mile 2366.8 to mile 2390.4
PCT Miles: 23.6 (37.8km)
Total Miles: 2390.4 (3824.6km)

Once more, cold wet morning. It didn’t rain but you could feel the wetness coming out of the moisture from the mist and leaves.

The star of the day were without a doubt the huckleberry fields!

When the first huckleberries  showed up still early in the morning, I couldn’t pick them because my fingers were too cold and I was unable to pinch 🫐🤏 . Gladly the fields lasted for the whole day and later, after a few uphills, I warmed up and could eat a fair share of huckleberries. For lunch I had the best electronola so far (with, of course, huckleberries)!

It was a lower-than-average mile day. I’m camping
close to Snoqualmie Pass (a ski resort), where I plan to spend the day and night tomorrow.

If everything goes according to the plan, I will get a resupply package (that I sent to a gas station in Snoqualmie Pass) for the coming three days. The idea is to stay there for the day and plan the last days of the PCT (including the last detour because of wildfires).

all_steps.name: Nearo into Snoqualmie Pass
all_steps.description:
Day 120
Mile 2390.4 to Snoqualmie Pass
PCT Miles: 5.4 (8.6km)
Total Miles: 2395.8 (3833.3km)

It was a double chill morning: it was really cold and the only time pressure I had was that the earlier I hiked the remaining 5.4 miles to “town”, the earlier I would have warm breakfast and hot coffee! 

Arrived at the coffee shop around 9am and stayed until noon with Jesse, Lily and Ranger (we all camped together last night). I got my resupply box at the gas station and sorted my food for the next days. 

From there I went to my accommodation: a chalet/lodge called Washington Alpine Club. They offer a good deal for hikers which includes dinner and breakfast, clean towels and loaner clothes (clothes to use while yours are being washed). Every guest has also to pick up a chore. Mine was to take the trash out.

I had the immense surprise of meeting Geezer one more time here at the WAC! I hadn’t seen him since I took the wrong trail in the Sierras, on day 50! We had pizza for lunch together and chatted about the past days! I really miss hiking with Geezer, Bullfrog and Tangent! The group that we kindly named the Harry Pottheads 🪄!

For dinner we had infinite spaghetti 🍝 and various salads 🥗. Some of the vegetables were
even grown at the property itself!

For the coming days, I’m going to slow down a little bit and I decided to bring a book. I found two books here that I could read and decided to bring The Adventures of Tom Sawyer with me. It’s the first time on the PCT that I’m carrying a book 📕!

all_steps.name: Beginning of the end
all_steps.description:
Day 121
Snoqualmie Pass to mile 2405.5
PCT Miles: 9.7 (15.5km)
Total Miles: 2405.5 (3848.8km)

After having infinite pancakes 🥞 and coffee for breakfast and helping with my chore at the “hostel” (take out the trash 🗑️) I slowly started making my way to the coffee shop to use the wifi to organize the next steps of the hike, including entering in Canada and understanding what to do and where to go once I cross the border. It really feels like it’s the beginning of the end!

Around noon I started my hiking day. I want to be at Steven’s Pass, where I will catch a bus to skip the upcoming wildfires, on Monday morning. This gives me 4 days to hike 71 miles, which is way below my average. That’s why I’m bringing a book with me for this section! 

The plan was to hike slowly and enjoy the views, but there were no views and it was too cold to hike slowly. I ended up making camp at 5pm after hiking 10 miles. 

It’s probably going to be very cold tonight but the good news is that I have absolutely no time pressure so I’ll take my time to wake up and break out camp, maybe even having a proper breakfast and hot tea before starting to hike 😋!

all_steps.name: White, wet and a goat. Plus sunshine!
all_steps.display_name: White, wet and a goat. Plus sunshine!
all_steps.description:
Day 122
Mile 2405.5 to mile 2426.3
PCT Miles: 20.8 (33.3km)
Total Miles: 2426.3 (3882.1km)

It rained most part of the night and it was raining in the morning when I woke up! I think it’s the first time that this happens on the PCT.

What was certainly the first time for me was making tea and having breakfast in the tent before even starting the hiking day. I need to be in Steven’s Pass only on Monday (60 miles away) so I’m taking my time. I left camp this morning at 8:30am 😎!

It was only the second time that I was wearing my rain jacket (the first was on day 58, in the Sierra). It didn’t rain for too long, but the fog persisted for the whole morning. Everything was wet and white.

Still in the morning, I saw a mountain goat for the first time. She gently left the trail and let me pass. It was the perfect encounter.

While I was having lunch (belvita cookies with a block of cheese 🍪🧀), the sky cleared and the sun started to shine. If you had told me in the morning that I would have sun today still, I wouldn’t have believed. Time to hang my tent to dry!

The afternoon was under sun and entirely uphill for 3 hours. At least this time I had some nice views!

all_steps.name: 20 miles for the last time
all_steps.description:
Day 123
Mile 2426.3 to mile 2447.4
PCT Miles: 21.1 (33.8km)
Total Miles: 2447.4 (3915.8km)

Against all the odds and forecasts, the morning was cloudless and sunny. The clear skies lasted for the whole day. I’m writing this at 6:30pm and it’s hard to believe that the forecast is, still, for thunderstorms and rain. It should start around 9pm.

Besides that no big surprises during the day. With no pressure for doing big miles, I took my time to hike at a lower pace and enjoy longer breaks. I was at camp before 5pm but unfortunately there are a few bugs around making my evening a bit less enjoyable.

Today was the last time I hiked 20 or more miles. It’s crazy to think that the end is less than one week away!

all_steps.name: Still beautiful Washington
all_steps.description:
Day 124
Mile 2447.4 to mile 2463.4
PCT Miles: 16.0 (25.6km)
Total Miles: 2463.4 (3941.4km)

I woke up first with an intense flash. If I wasn’t already awake, the massive thunder that came a few seconds later would certainly do the job.

Even though I was a bit scared in the beginning, I soon fell asleep again. The thunderstorm lasted for about two hours, but it rained the whole night until morning. I had to break out camp (and dig a cat hole) under rain.

My tent and some of my stuff were wet, but nothing extreme. Truth be told, everything held up well and I was very warm and dry during the night. During the day the sun showed up for a little bit, more than enough time for me to hang my tent to dry.

Washington is beautiful and even with the fog and rain I’ve been enjoying a lot to hike here. Once more: it’s super cool to see how many people come to hike and camp over the weekends (it’s Sunday). I saw a lot of day hikers and weekenders today.

all_steps.name: Nearo into Steven’s Pass
all_steps.description:
Day 125, part 1
Mile 2463.4 to Steven’s Pass
PCT Miles: 3.4 (5.4km)
Total Miles: 2466.8 (3946.9km)

It didn’t rain during the night but everything I had was a bit (very) wet this morning due the wet ground and the condensation. To make the situation slightly more uncomfortable, I left one of my shoes kind of not exactly under the rain fly: in the morning it had a little pool inside the shoe.

Packing and breaking out camp was horrible but the prospect of hot coffee and town food helped with the motivation. My tent was so wet that it lept dripping from my backpack on my butt for the whole 3.4 miles to Steven’s Pass (which is basically a mini convenience store).

Two large lattes and few snacks later, at 11:30am, me, Sarah, Pete and Nick took the bus to the curious town of Leavenworth (where I had my last resupply box waiting for me).

all_steps.name: Quick stop at Leavenworth
all_steps.description:
Day 125, part 2

Leavenworth must be the most curious village I’ve been in the PCT. It’s fully themed with a Bavarian-style (even the Mc Donald’s and Starbucks signs are Bavarianized!) and the bakeries, restaurants and saloons all serve german beer and food.

I was here for a little bit more than two hours: just enough to grab my last resupply and take another bus to Wenatchee.

The location for this resupply box clearly was not ideal, since I have nothing else to do here. When I sent it, on day 113, I was not sure of what to do. 

Unfortunately I’ll have to skip a few more miles
of the PCT due five (yes, FIVE) different wildfires that are burning ahead of me: Shoofly, Miner’s Complex, Pioneer, Flat Creek and Easy.

That will take me more than one day of travel (including today). Soon I’ll take a free bus 🆓🚌 to the city of Wenatchee where I’ll stay in a hotel for the night, dry all my gear, do laundry and hopefully eat a good pizza. Tomorrow I’ll take a bus to Pateros, then another to Twisp and from there take another bus to Mazama, where I’ll try to camp and get a ride to Hart’s Pass (where I continue the PCT). My goal is to arrive there with enough time to chill and start hiking on Wednesday (today is Monday).

all_steps.name: Overnight in Wenatchee
all_steps.description:
Day 125, part 3

It’s so funny how I’m still not used to be in the US: on google maps, it shows that from the bus stop to my hotel is only two blocks. From the hotel to the laundromat, two more blocks. Then, two more blocks to the convenience store. Easy peasy! Except that every block takes a lifetime to walk.

I spent my whole afternoon walking on the infinite sidewalks taking care of annoying details of my town chores: I had to walk for almost an hour to exchange my bills into coins, so I could pay the laundry machine. I also had to rearrange the furniture in my hotel room to fit all the hanging-to-dry gear that’s spread around. At least I got my pizza!

Tomorrow it’s a zero, but it’s a looong travel day.

all_steps.name: Bus bus bus
all_steps.description:
Day 126, part 1
Steven’s Pass to Mazama 
PCT Miles: skipped from 2466.8 to 2624.7 (157.9 miles) due to Shoofly, Miner’s Complex, Pioneer, Flat Creek and Easy fires.
Total Miles: 2624.7 (4199.5km)

The section that I had to skip today was the most hurtful of all the skipped miles of the trail. Washington has been absolutely gorgeously incredibly beautiful. Challenging with its steep hills, rainy and cold, but also very rewarding with magnificent views of lakes and mountains. Maybe it’s because the wound is too recent, but I feel like Washington is the only section of the PCT that I would like to do again, in whole. Who knows?

I had an entirely free morning! At 6am I was already eating the hot breakfast at the hotel like an animal 🦔. At 7 was at the hotel’s spa, alternating between using the jacuzzi with few laps on the cold swimming pool 🏊. Around 10am I was already fully packed and slowly walking towards the bus station in the “old downtown” of Wenatchee.

My first stop was at an amazing book store.  I spent more than an hour browsing through the store until finally I exchanged my Adventures of Tom Sawyer (I absolutely couldn’t read it: I didn’t understand a thing after reading 10 pages) for Battlestar Galactica. After that. it was time for second breakfast in a nice coffee shop!

From there I ended up at a nice market hall with a bit of everything: food, coffee, local art, breweries. Time for another break!

At 2:30pm I finally got into the bus to Pateros, where I would then take a bus to Twisp and finally take a final bus to Mazama, where I need to find a shuttle/trail angel to bring me to the trailhead. Well, one step at a time (not literally, unfortunately).

We saw one of the fires that were ahead of us from very, very close. Even the driver was clearly a bit uncomfortable to be driving kind of towards the fire. In the end everything was fine and it was actually cool to see the helicopters 🚁 attacking the fire and creating the containment lines.

On this first bus we were 4 hikers. After arriving in Pateros, we became 8, since four other hikers arrived while we were waiting the bus to Twisp. We, PCT hikers, were the only passengers on the next buses, finally arriving in Manzama a bit after 6pm. Almost four hours of bus rides today 😮‍💨.

All the eight of us had the same plan: go to this “Lion’s Den” place in that we heard about to spend the night and go to the Hart’s Pass trailhead tomorrow morning. So we all went together to Lion’s Den. And that was a cool place to be!

all_steps.name: Lion’s Den
all_steps.description:
Day 126, part 2

At Lion’s Den they have a few beds, virtually unlimited space to camp and a “hiker hut” which is a mini-chalet with a kitchen, bathroom and common area for the hikers. Everything is donation based.

This year, with so many fires around this region, hikers are arriving here with too much food (like
me). The result is that the hiker boxes are not only completely full, but full with good stuff. So here you also eat and drink as much as you want for free. 

This was my favorite stay on the PCT. It felt a little bittersweet to leave this morning instead of taking a zero like the other hikers, since I’m in no rush. On the other hand 🖐️ I cannot wait to finish the PCT. Two. More. Days.

all_steps.name: Last night on the PCT
all_steps.description:
Day 127
Ride from Mazama to Hart’s Pass, then Harts’s Pass to mile 2638.3
PCT Miles: 13.6 (21.8km)
Total Miles: 2638.3 (4221.3km)

From Lion’s Den there’s a trail angel who does shuttles to Hart’s Pass, about one our ride. There was a full van leaving at 6:30am and I was scheduled to leave with two other hikers at 9:30am.

With time to spare in the morning, I used one of the loaner bikes 🚲 that they have here and went to the bakery. I had the best cinnamon roll that I ever had in my life, hands down. Good start for the penultimate day on the PCT!

At 9:30am, the two other hikers decided to take a zero (they were vortexed by the Lion’s Den and the cinnamon rolls) and I was the only hiker in the shuttle. I could lay down and I literally took a half hour nap!

On the trail itself nothing special. It’s pretty cold, but hopefully it won’t rain and I’ll stay dry for my last day! 

While I was having dinner, two southbounders arrived and joined me at camp: it was Pete and Nick! They finished the PCT earlier today and now they’re hiking back, since they don’t want hike into Canada.

all_steps.name: 🏁
all_steps.description:
Day 128
Mile 2638.3 to PCT Northern Terminus Monument
PCT Miles: 16.9 (27.0km)
Total Miles: 2655.2 (4248.3km)

Since early in the morning, I felt that today was meant to be emotional. Today was my last day hiking the PCT.

I woke up at 5:30 with Pete and Nick breaking out camp already. Pete’s wife was at Hart’s Pass waiting for him: they would drive together back home in south Idaho. Nick still has one month of visa and decided to stay in the US until the last day he can. He is going to Seattle now and then “we will see”.

After shaking their hands (an act that is not very common on the PCT: for hygienic reasons hikers usually greet each other with fist-bumps), I said “yeah dudes. Nice to meet you both. See you next time!”. Pete laughed. “Next time”. We all knew this is the last time I’m seeing both of them.

Soon after 6am I was already on my last ascend and my last pass on the PCT. I heard this morning from another hiker that this is actually the highest point in Washington that’s part of the PCT. It was cold and at some point it started to rain. I couldn’t have cared less.

I crossed paths with at least 15 other hikers coming back from the Northern Terminus Monument: most hikers don’t cross to Canada and instead, after finishing the PCT, they go back to Hart’s Pass and find a ride back to civilization. You could see that most of them had red eyes showing that they had been crying recently. 

For the last time I saw Ranger, Hélène, Ghost, Ranger, Ruud, Marieke, Jägermeister, Wind-up and Golden Shower. At every hiker coming on the opposite direction, the same gesture repeated: a fist bump followed by a “congrats, you did it!”. Despite the excitement, everybody (including myself) looked absolutely exhausted.

The last three hikers that I crossed with before reaching the terminus told me the same thing, as if they were trying to somehow alert me. They all said that reaching the terminus was very emotional, that they started crying as soon as they saw the monument and kept crying for a few minutes. I was not sure what to expect.

The last person ahead of me was Ghost. Ruud and Marieke were the closest hikers behind me and they were more than one hour back. When I crossed paths with Ghost coming back from the terminus, I knew that I would be alone at the monument for as long as I wanted. I would have all the time I wanted to be emotional.

And there it was. In a small clearance in the middle of nowhere, at the border between the United Stated and Canada, the end marker of the Pacific Crest Trail: the Northern Terminus Monument.

I cheered with a beer that I had brought from Lion’s Den, took a few photos, signed the trail record. Sat down and relaxed for a bit, ate a few snacks. I waited for the tears to roll down my face and for my emotional discharge to start.

It didn’t take long for me to realize that it just wouldn’t happen. And I believe I know exactly the reason why.

For me, the decision to hike the PCT (or the other long distance trails that I hiked before) never had an emotional factor. The main aspect that thrills me on those hikes is the adventure itself. I really enjoy the physical challenges and all the research and planning around these hikes. I like to learn knew things (I did so many things for the first time in the past four months, like wild camping or glissading a frozen mountain).

My two main rules for the PCT (1. don’t die and 2. make wise decisions) are straightforward rules to make sure that I’ll (literally) stay alive and complete my objective. Finishing the PCT has always been my main goal and every step I took (literally) in that direction came from a very analytical decision, not emotional.

I always trusted that my body would be able to deal with all the challenges imposed by the PCT. During the past 128 days, I had only one blister that really bothered me (Bloopu 🫶), a discomfort on my right knee and ankle (in and after the Sierra, when I broke my pole and had to hike with only one) and the soles of my feet that complained a bit after hiking for almost 5 weeks for more than 500 miles without a single rest day in NorCal and Oregon. I didn’t have a single headache. I’m happy to report that I had zero stomach issues. My body is my temple.

By the way, one of the most challenging tasks during the PCT was to kept this diary here and writing every single day on trail. I’m really proud of myself that I kept up with that! I hope you all enjoyed 😊!

I finished my beer and look at the time. Twenty minutes had passed since I arrived at the monument. I felt weird to be enjoying such a long pause. My brain apparently still hadn’t had processed that it was all over. Well, to be honest I still had to hike 8 miles to arrive in civilization in Canada. 

I got up, pack on my back for the last time and continued to hike for four more hours. No tears, no epiphanies, no emotional rollercoaster. I’m just feeling the bliss of finalizing something that I have worked so hard to accomplish. I’m feeling complete.

————

Thank you so much for each and every one of you who followed me along in this adventure. All the likes, comments and follow requests that I received here really (really!) motivated me to keep going. I hope I could inspire some of you to go out there and seek for your own adventures (maybe hiking the PCT? 🙃).

Thank you for my official support team! Special thanks to my friend Bruno who clearly had a lot of free time in his hands to keep commenting a lot of nonsense. And a super, mega, huge thanks to Chris who did so much (maybe too much!) to help me with the logistics over here. Thank you, thank you, thank you 🙏!

If you enjoyed the PCT, I encourage you to check out an incredible hike that I did with Maike 💜 (and Tani 💙 and Kyra 💚!) last year: the Shikoku Henro Pilgrimage. It should be visible on my trips now (it was on Maike’s account but apparently we can share a trip with multiple accounts now). Go, check it out!

Once more, thank you all so much! See you all next time 😉! 

Bruno
